LEX-FAOC047832;"Environment Act 2001.";"This Act makes provision for the establishment of the National Environment Council
column2: the Lesotho Environment Authority
column3: the National Environmental Fund and the Environmental Tribunal and provides in general for the conservation and management of the environment in Lesotho.The Act consists of 123 sections divided into 16 Parts: Preliminary (I); General Principles (II); Institutional Arrangements (III); Environmental Planning (IV); Environmental Impact Assessment
column4: Audits and Monitoring (V); Environmental Quality Standards (VI); Pollution Control (VII); Environmental Management (VIII); Environmental Restoration Order (IX); Inspection
column5: Analysis And Record (X); International Environmental Conventions (XI); Information
column6: Education and Public Awareness (XII); Financial Provisions (XIII); Environmental Tribunal (XIV); Offences (XV) ; Miscellaneous (XVI).Section 3 sets out principles of environmental management. The National Environment Council established under section 5 as the supreme body at Government level for the formulation of policy for purposes of this Act. The supreme body in the formulation of policy for purposes of this Act
column7: established under section 9
column8: as a body corporate
column9: shall be the principal agency for the management of the environment and carry out functions set out in section 10. The governing body of the Authority shall be a Board of Directors. There shall be a Chief Executive of the Authority who shall be appointed by the Minister (sect. 17). The Authority shall every five years prepare a National Environmental Action Plan in accordance with section 25. Environmental planning at district level shall be done by District Development Coordinating Committees in accordance with section 26. An environment impact assessment shall be undertaken on projects and activities specified in the Schedule to this Act (sect. 27). The Authority shall
column10: in consultation with the relevant Ministry establish standards for the quality of water
column11: the quality of air
column12: the quality of soil
column13: waste
column14: noise
column15: ionization and other radiation and guidelines for environmental disasters (Part VI). Part VIII on environmental management provides for a wide variety of matters such as identification and protection of hilly and mountainous areas
column16: re-forestation and afforestation of hilly and mountainous areas
column17: protection of rivers
column18: river banks or wetlands etc.
column19: general and specific orders
column20: for standards for the management of rivers
column21: river banks
column22: lakes
column23: lake shore and wetlands
column24: protection of forests
column25: conservation of energy and planting of trees or woodlots
column26: conservation of Biological Diversity and biological resources in situ and ex-situ
column27: access to genetic resources of Lesotho
column28: management of range lands
column31: protection of natural environmental areas
column33: management of dangerous materials and the management of (hazardous) waste. The Authority may issue to any person
column34: in respect of a matter relating to the management of the environment and natural resources
column35: an environmental restoration order pursuant to Part IX. Section 89 concerns the designation of environmental inspectors. The National Environment Fund is established under section 98. The fund shall be administered by the Authority and the object for which the Fund is established is the protection
column36: enhancement and management of the environment and natural resources in Lesotho. Regulation making powers of the Minister are set out in section 122.

column1: LEX-FAOC047831;"Environment Protection Act 2002 (No. 19 of 2002).";"The Act makes provision for the establishment
column2: functions and powers
column3: organization
column4: etc. of the National Environment Commission
column5: the Department of Environment and other public bodies involved in the administration of environmental affairs
column6: for the pollution prevention measures and environmental impact assessment
column7: the establishment of the Issue of standards and guidelines
column8: the issue of environmental standards and guidelines
column9: and for various other maters relating to environment protection.The Act consists of 100 sections divided into 13 Parts: Preliminary (I); Administration (II); Enforcing Agencies (III); Environmental Impact Assessment (IV); Spill and Environmental Emergency (V); National Environmental Standards (VI); Coastal and Maritime Zone Management (VII); The Environment Appeal Tribunal (VIII); The National Environment Fund (IX); Environment Protection Fee (X); Enforcement (XI); Application of Act to Rodrigues (XII); Miscellaneous Provisions (XIII).Section 4 sets out the geographical Application sphere of the Act. The National Environment Commission established under section 5 shall set national objectives and goals
column10: and determine policies and priorities for the protection of the environment
column11: having due regard to the recommendations of the Minister and monitor
column12: coordinate and supervise environmental management at a national level in accordance with section 6. Powers of the Minister to whom responsibility for the subject of the environment is assigned are set out in section 7. The Department of Environment
column13: established within the Ministry responsible for the environment
column14: shall be administered by Director of Environment
column15: the duties of which are set out in section 8. Section 9 provides for a Police de l'Environnement. There is established for the purposes of this Act a National Network for Sustainable Development under section 10. The objects of the National Network for Sustainable Development shall be to act as a forum for discussions and consultations on matters set out in section 11. There shall be such enforcing agencies as are designated in the Fourth Schedule in respect of such environmental medium
column16: or such pollutant
column17: as is specified (sect. 13). There shall be for the purposes of this Act an Environment Coordination Committee which shall ensure the maximum cooperation and coordination among enforcing agencies and other public departments dealing with environment protection
column18: and carry out other duties listed in section 14. The First Schedule lists activities for which an Environmental Impact Assessment is required (sects. 15 to 18). An EIA Committee is established under section 22. Subject to section 37
column19: the Minister may
column20: for the protection and management of the environment
column21: issue guidelines published in the Gazette on any of the environment segments listed in that section. Detailed rules for such standards and guidelines are set out in sections 38-48. An Integrated Coastal Zone Management Committee is established under section 50. The Committee shall develop an integrated management plan for coastal and maritime zones and carry out other duties listed in section 50. An Environment Appeal Tribunal is established under section 53. The Tribunal shall hear and determine appeals in matters listed in section 54. The National Environment Fund
column22: established under section 59 shall pursue the objectives set out in section 60. The Fund shall be administered by a Board. Director of Environment may take various enforcement measures
column23: mainly in the form of issuing notices and orders
column24: pursuant to provisions of Part XI. The Minister may
column25: after consultation with the Committee
column26: cause to be published in the Gazette codes of practice for the purpose of providing practical guidance with respect to appropriate pollution control technology
column27: and generally with respect to the protection of the environment under section 95 and make Regulations under section 96.

column1: LEX-FAOC047834;"Environmental Management Act [Chapter 20:27].";"This Act provides for the establishment of the National Environmental Council
column2: the Environmental Management Agency
column3: Environment Management Board
column4: the Standards and Enforcement Committee and the Environment Fund
column5: provides for the formulation of environmental quality standards and environmental plans
column6: provides for environmental impact assessments audit and monitoring of projects and for other matters relative to management and conservation of the environment.The Act consists of 143 sections divided into 16 Parts: Preliminary (I); General Principles of Environmental Management and Functions of Minister (II); National Environmental Council (III); Environmental Management Agency (IV); Environment Management Board (V); Staff of Agency (VI); Financial Provisions Relating to Agency (VII); Environment Fund (VIII); Environmental Quality Standards (IX); Environmental Plans (X); Environmental Impact Assessments Audit and Monitoring of Projects (XI); Conservation and Improvement of Environment (XII); Conservation and Improvement of Environment (XIII); Appeals (XIV); Internal Obligations and Commitments (XV); General (XVI). The Act is completed by six Schedules.Section 4 outlines environmental rights and principles of environmental management. Section 5 defines the general functions of the Minister of Environment and Tourism. The Minister may delegate to the Environmental Management Agency
column7: established under section 9
column8: or the National Environment Council
column9: established under section 7
column10: such of his functions under this Act as he thinks fit. The Council shall advise on policy formulation and give directions on the implementation of this Act and carry out other functions outlined in section 8. The Agency shall be a body corporate and be responsible for the formulation of quality standards on air
column11: water
column12: soil
column13: noise
column14: vibration
column15: radiation and waste management
column16: for the regulation and monitoring of the collection
column17: disposal
column18: treatment and recycling of waste and the discharge or emission of any pollutant or hazardous substance into the environment
column19: and shall carry out other functions listed in section 10. The Environment Management Board
column20: established under section 11
column21: shall manage and control the operations of the Agency. The management and control of the Environment Fund
column22: established under section 48
column23: shall he vested
column24: subject to this Act
column25: in the Minister as trustee of the Fund. The Minister
column26: in consultation with the Board and with the approval of the Minister responsible for finance
column27: may by notice in a statutory instrument
column28: impose an environment levy on any person or class of persons whose activities impact on the environment (sect. 50). Objects of Fund are set out in section 52. A Standards and Enforcement Committee is established as a committee of the Board (sect. 55). The Standards and Enforcement Committee shall
column30: advise the Board on water quality standards in accordance with section 56. Section 57 introduces a general prohibition to pollute water. The Board shall maintain a register of all effluent discharge licences issued under this Act (sect. 62). The Committee shall also prescribe standards for air quality
column31: waste
column35: and noxious smells. Every pesticides or toxic substance shall be registered under section 76. The Minister shall prepare a National Environmental Plan (sect. 87). Contents of the Plan are outlined in section 88. Every local authority shall prepare an environmental action plan for the area under its jurisdiction in accordance with such directions as the Minister may give (sect. 95). Projects listed in the First Schedule are activities for which environmental impact assessment required (sect. 97). Contents of environmental impact assessment report are outlined in section 99. The President may set aside State land or acquire other land for environmental purposes pursuant to section 109. The Minister may declare any wetland to be an ecologically sensitive area and may impose limitations on development in or around such area (sect. 113) and may make an order for protection of environment pursuant to section 114. An Inspector may also make an order pursuant to section 115. The Minister shall take such measures as may be necessary for the conservation of biological diversity and the implementation of Zimbabwe’s obligations under the Convention on Biological Diversity of 1992 (sect. 116) and
column36: on the recommendations of the Agency
column39: control or restrict access by any person to the biological and genetic resources of Zimbabwe (sect. 117).

column1: LEX-FAOC152763;"Política Nacional de la Mujer: Primer Plan Nacional de Igualdad de Oportunidades
column2: 2002-2007.";"El presente documento tiene por objeto la Política Nacional de la Mujer y el Primer Plan Nacional de Igualdad de Oportunidades
column3: de alcance nacional y relativo al período 2002-2007. El objetivo general es garantizar los derechos de las mujeres hondureñas y luchar contra la pobreza de las mismas. El Plan Nacional define los siguientes cinco ejes prioritarios: 1) Salud; 2) Educación y Medios de Comunicación; 3) Participación Social y Política; 4) Economía y Pobreza; 5) Violencia.El Plan prevé acciones para fortalecer las estrategias del Programa Nacional de Desarrollo Rural Sostenible para promover la seguridad alimentaria. El Capítulo 1 del Plan
column4: dedicado a la salud
column5: establece como lineamiento de política formular planes y programas de salud con enfoque de género
column6: para promover un estado de salud óptimo en las mujeres
column7: a lo largo de su ciclo de vida.El Plan brinda especial atención a las mujeres de las áreas rurales y otras zonas postergadas del país. En este sentido el lineamiento de política definido en el Capítulo 3 (Economía y Pobreza) contempla realizar acciones que permitan el ejercicio de los derechos económicos de la mujer y la reducción de los índices de pobreza desde una perspectiva de igualdad de oportunidades entre géneros. Asimismo se contempla ejecutar programas y proyectos de formación
column8: para fortalecer las capacidades productivas y gerenciales de las mujeres como sujetos económicos
column9: en rubros tradicionales y no tradicionales.Otra de las acciones contempladas en el Capítulo 3 consiste en desarrollar programas y proyectos que fomenten la participación de las mujeres
column10: como propietarias de los medios de producción
column11: en sectores dinámicos de la economía
column12: incluyendo rubros de exportación. Asimismo
column13: con respecto a la tierra y los recursos productivos
column14: se prevé: a) revisar y aplicar la legislación agrícola
column15: forestal
column16: ambiental y otras leyes vigentes
column17: para garantizar la equidad de género en el acceso
column18: uso y control de los recursos productivos; b) identificar fondos de tierra para mujeres campesinas de acuerdo a la demanda
column19: otorgando prioridad a jefas de familia que viven en condiciones de pobreza; c) promover programas y proyectos productivos
column20: y de protección al medio ambiente
column21: con participación equitativa de mujeres y hombres; d) agilizar el funcionamiento de las cajas de ahorro y crédito y flexibilizar los requerimientos de créditos para capital semilla
column22: contemplados en la Ley para la Modernización y Desarrollo del Sector Agrícola.En el marco de la gobernanza
column23: se contempla promover la elaboración de una propuesta conjunta entre el gobierno
column24: organizaciones de mujeres y mujeres empresarias
column25: para impulsar su participación en el proceso de integración económica.

column1: LEX-FAOC152779;"Planning (Wales) Act 2015 (2015 anaw 4).";"This Act concerns development planning in Wales. It makes provision about sustainable development in the exercise of functions relating to development planning and applications for planning permission. The Act
column2: among other things: provides for the preparation and revision of a National Development Framework for Wales and for the designation of strategic planning areas
column3: the establishment of strategic planning panels and the preparation of strategic development plans; require applications for planning permission for development of national significance in Wales to be made to the Welsh Ministers instead of a local planning authority; provide with respect to consultations on development; make amendments to other legislation including the Water Resources Act 1991 and the Environment Act 1995. The Welsh Ministers may by Regulations— (a) designate an area in Wales as a strategic planning area for the purposes of this Part
column4: and (b) establish a strategic planning panel for that area. The Act also concerns certain matters concerning village greens (common property).

column1: LEX-FAOC123198;"Regional Law No. 66-OZ “On ensuring fertility of agricultural land”.";"The scope of this Regional Law shall be to ensure fertility of agricultural land by owners
column2: landlords
column3: land tenants and leaseholders. The main arrangements for ensuring soil fertility shall be: (a) elaboration and realization of regional programs; (b) soil
column4: agrochemical
column5: phytosanitary
column6: ecological and toxicological inspection; (c) investments in soil conservation and reproduction; and (d) improvement of soil quality and fertility. Owners
column7: tenants and leaseholders of agricultural land must: (a) prevent soil pollution
column8: littering and degradation; (b) carry out agricultural production by methods ensuring reproduction of soil fertility and preventing negative environmental impact; (c) inform authorized institutions of soil pollution and degradation of agricultural land; and (d) not apply ecologically hazardous fertilizers
column9: ameliorators and pesticides.

column1: LEX-FAOC123193;"Regional Law No. 174-OZ “On expropriation of public or municipal land for public and municipal needs”.";"This Regional Law establishes cases of expropriation
column2: including repayment
column3: of public or municipal land for public and municipal needs. Expropriation shall be performed in the following cases: (a) for public construction in accordance with land-use planning projects; (b) for realization of regional and municipal programs; (c) for conservation of the objects of cultural heritage in public ownership; (d) institution of new or extension of already existing protected areas; and (e) construction and reconstruction of objects partially or completely financed out of regional or local budget.

column1: LEX-FAOC030820;"Ministerial Decree No. 273 of 2000 regarding validation of the Regulation on state geodetic survey over geodetic and cartographic activity.";"The Government decrees to validate the Regulation. State Geodetic Survey over Geodetic and Cartographic Activity is carried out for the purpose of ensuring observance of the Russian Legislation on geodesy and cartography by all the parties involved in the sphere of relationship of geodesy and cartography. The Federal Service of Geodesy and Cartography carry out state Geodetic Survey. The main tasks of State Geodetic Survey are: 1). Supervision over cadastre (land-surveying) activity
column2: elaboration of geo-information systems and other geodetic and cartographic activity in accordance with legislative and normative acts. 2). Supervision over the correct representation of state border
column3: the territory of the Russian Federation
column4: its continental shelf and Exclusive Economic Zone
column5: the territorial boundaries of the Regions and municipal units within the jurisdiction of the Russian Federation. 2). Licensing of geodetic and cartographic activity. 3). Registration of geodetic and cartographic work. Persons obstructing the accomplishment of State Geodetic Survey are liable to prosecution in accordance with the Russian Legislation currently in force. Federal Service of Geodesy and Cartography elaborates in co-ordination with other Federal Executive Bodies concerned and validates normative and technical documentation regarding carrying out state geodetic survey.

column2: con fines de saneamiento físico legal y formalización del territorio de las Comunidades Nativas.";"La presente Resolución aprueba los Lineamientos para la ejecución y aprobación de estudios de levantamiento de suelos para la clasificación de tierras por su capacidad de uso mayor (CTCUM)
column3: con fines de saneamiento físico legal y formalización del territorio de las Comunidades Nativas
column4: que se establecen sobre la base del interés público para la titulación del territorio de las Comunidades Nativas
column5: el cual tiene como limitación la aptitud forestal de la tierra
column6: supuesto en el cual solo se entrega en cesión en uso. La Dirección General de Asuntos Ambientales Agrarios del MINAGRI es responsable de la ejecución
column7: supervisión
column8: promoción y difusión de la Clasifi cación de las Tierras por su Capacidad de Uso Mayor (CTCUM)
column9: y en tal sentido
column10: el órgano formalizador del Gobierno Regional podrá solicitar a dicha Dirección General la información de la CTCUM que pudieran estar contenidos en los Estudios de Inventario y Evaluación de los Recursos Naturales.

column1: LEX-FAOC164254;"Public Nuisance Dispute Mediation Act.";"This Act is enacted to fairly
column2: promptly and effectively handle public nuisance disputes
column3: to safeguard the rights and interests of the people
column4: and to improve social harmony. It consists of 51 articles divided into 4 Chapters: General Provisions; Organizations Handling Public Disputes; Settlement Procedures; Supplementary Provisions.The “public nuisance” in this Act means human activities which destroy the living environment
column5: and damage or endanger public health. Such activities include water pollution
column7: soil pollution
column8: noise
column9: vibration
column10: noxious odors
column11: waste
column12: toxic substance pollution
column13: land subsidence
column14: radioactive pollution and other activities designated and officially announced as public nuisances by the central competent authority (art.2).Chapter 2 provides for the establishment of Mediation Committee and the Arbitration Panel. Each special municipality
column15: county or city government shall establish a public nuisance dispute mediation committee to settle public nuisance disputes. The Environmental Protection Agency
column16: Executive Yuan
column17: shall set up a Public Nuisance Dispute Arbitration Panel to arbitrate public nuisance disputes over damage claims unresolved by mediation procedures.Chapter 3 further provides for procedures of mediation and arbitration.

column2: including components
column3: accessories and soil value the present Ordinance shall be applied. The text consists of 24 articles divided into 4 Parts as follows: Sphere of application
column4: definition of terms and general land assessment principles (1); Soil values and other necessary data (2); Assessment proceedings (3); Final provisions (4).Two Annexes are enclosed.

column1: LEX-FAOC152766;"Afar National Regional State Rural Lands Administration and Use Proclamation No. 49/2009.";"This Proclamation of the Afar National Regional State establishes a rural land administration system that is suitable for natural resource management and protection and that incentivizes investment within the traditional clan-based communal land tenure system. Laws that pertain to lands designated as forest lands
column2: wildlife sanctuaries
column3: biodiversity protected lands
column4: environmental and natural resource conservation and preservation areas shall not be affected by this Proclamation. The Proclamation
column5: among other things: provides for survey
column7: certification etc. of the rural land use rights of pastoralists and provides for dispute resolution in respect of such rights; provides registration etc. of land use rights of agro-pastoralists; provides with respect to transfer of rights in rural lands; provides for rural land allocation and redistribution; defines duties and obligations of rural land holders and land use restrictions; requires the competent authority to develop a guiding master land use plan for land use with particular attention to water resource management; requires an equitable water use system to be established between upper and lower riparian communities; places restriction on free grazing on rural land where soil and water conservation measures have been undertaken; prohibit farming and free grazing on land the slope of which is more than 60 percent and requires trees to be planted on such land; ensure payment of fair and equitable compensation in case of expropriation of land of agro-pastoralists; provides for the rehabilitation of degraded communal land.

column1: LEX-FAOC039809;"Regulation on utilization and protection of agricultural lands.";"The Regulation provides principles and procedures for the protection and proper utilization of agricultural lands. Non-agricultural use of agricultural lands is determined by taking its classification
column2: use and agricultural features into consideration and does not include the following: (i) productive
column3: cultivated lands and irrigated lands (irrigation grades I
column4: II
column5: III
column6: IV and rain feeding grades I
column7: II); (ii) Lands presenting soil degradation due to drainage problems and salinity
column8: but with the potential for rehabilitation; (iii) Lands that are totally degraded but that could endanger projects ongoing in the area or that could possibly endanger agricultural activities in adjacent lands; (iv)Irrigated agricultural lands cannot be used for non-agricultural purposes. The exceptions apply in case of the construction of roads and railroads: when building dams
column9: excavating ponds and wells
column10: or setting up power stations
column11: facilities for waste treatment or the exploitation of oil and natural gas resources: when laying power transmission lines: when building traffic control and security stations
column12: defence facilities
column13: and airports. Permission to use irrigated agricultural lands shall be granted only when no other land parcels are available in the appointed area.

column1: LEX-FAOC152366;"Surveying (Cadastral Surveys) Regulations
column2: 2015.";"The objectives of these Regulations
column3: consisting of 17 sections and completed by four Schedules
column4: are to: (a) prescribe standards for cadastral surveys; (b) regulate and control the making of cadastral surveys by licensed surveyors; and (c) prescribe forms and other matters relating to cadastral surveys. These Regulations are made under section 63 of the Surveying Act 2004.The Surveyors Board has powers and functions relating to the registration
column5: training and certification of surveyors (sect. 8). The Act further provides for application for registration
column6: issue of certificates of registration and letters of accreditation
column7: cancellation and suspension
column8: appeals and offences. Section 26 describes the powers of the surveyors regarding entry upon land.

column1: LEX-FAOC071489;"Public Purpose Land Exchange Authorization Act of 1937 (P.L. 5-33).";"This Act authorizes the Marianas Public Land Corporation to enter into agreements by which the Government obtains freehold interest in private land in exchange for a freehold interest in private land to be assigned to a private landowner.Exchange of land shall be authorized for a public purpose as defined by this Act. The Act sets out the conditions at which an agreement may be made and defines some terms of the agreement. The Corporation may exchange land at its own initiative but “protected resources” and adjacent areas shall be excluded from public lands that may be exchanged. “Protected resources” include coastal zones
column2: public parks and ecologically sensitive areas. “Public purpose” shall include the acquisition of privately owned wetlands and other environmentally sensitive areas.

column1: LEX-FAOC152365;"The Second National Environmental Action Programme.";"The Second National Environmental Action Programme is a sectoral national programme of the Republic of Armenia applicable to the period 2008-2012. Its main objective is to provide a systematized package of environmental policy instruments to minimize the pressure on the natural environment.Among the measures aiming for environmental protection
column2: the Programme pertains to management of various types of natural resources. Among them
column3: it covers the issue of land resource management. In this area
column4: the document provides for various measures
column5: including (1) the revision of the classification principle of land resources
column6: separating the notions of “land use categories” and “legal regime of land use”
column7: thus improving the registration system of land fund and inputting new zoning system for land use and documentation for area planning; (2) enhancing the supervision over the land use and preservation by implementing national
column8: regional
column9: community project targeting land use and preservation; (3) reduction and prevention of land degradation
column10: aiming at organization of anti-erosion
column11: anti-land-sliding and ameliorative activities
column12: implementation of measures for restoration (re-cultivation) of degraded lands
column13: definition of principles for privatized agricultural land consolidation; (4) creation of Geographic Information Systems based on modern technologies with the application of environmental monitoring criteria; and (5) allocating lands located outside the administrative boundaries of the communities
column14: transfer of powers to the communities to ensure the prevention of land degradation and biodiversity conservation.With regard to the ecosystem management
column15: the Programme aims to (1) introduce biodiversity accounting
column16: inventory and monitoring systems; (2) set quotes for bio-diversity use
column17: assessment of human-induced and nature caused impact on the use of natural resources; (3) optimization of the Specially Protected Areas (SPA) system in line with modern approaches and principles; (4) in view of the long-pending idea of the communities on establishing community forests
column18: to envisage reforestation of no less than 3
column19: 000 ha community territories by mean of attracting various financial sources and innovative financial mechanisms
column20: which will at the same time specify active measures to fight fires and pests; (5) carry out an appropriate research to clarify the time-frame for implementing the measures as stipulated under the National Forest Programme of Armenia before 2012; (6) develop and implement pilot project on availability of genetic resources in the community and fair distribution of the benefits obtained from its use aiming to create prerequisites for conservation of Armenian genetic variety and balanced use of genetic resources.Finally
column21: the Programme treats the issue of water management. In this area
column22: it notes that one of the most important prerequisites of appropriate management of water resources is the assessment and classification of water reserves and resources of the Republic
column23: which will in turn allow making decisions related to the expansion of the strategic water reserves and regulation of river flow. Among other important directions is the development of global water resource management
column24: which will require elaboration of projects for surface and underground water resources monitoring based on the river basin approach. Another direction relates to definition and conservation of water ecosystems reservation zones (of sanitary conservation
column25: flow formation
column26: underwater conservation
column27: water protection zones
column28: ecotone
column30: as well as the development of methodology for determining the volumes of ecological outlets on the basis of hydro-geographical characteristics.The state policy for environmental protection and reasonable use of natural resources is developed and implemented by the Ministry of Nature Protection of the Republic of Armenia. The functions assigned to the Ministry of Nature Protection are implemented by the structural and detached units of the ministry personnel and state non-profit organizations and companies established within the ministry system.

column1: LEX-FAOC047632;"Protection of the Environment Act 2003.";"The Environmental Protection Agency shall be the competent authority for the purposes of the Directive on integrated pollution prevention and control here implemented. As competent authority for the purposes of the Directive
column2: the Agency shall
column3: amongst other things
column4: keep itself informed of developments in best available techniques. A new section added to the Environmental Protection Agency Act 1992 prescribes that the Minister may
column5: for the purposes of relation to environmental protection
column6: make Regulations providing for the carrying out by the Agency or a local authority of environmental inspections in connection with the performance of a statutory function of the Agency or a local authority in relation to environmental protection. The Agency may revoke
column7: or suspend the operation of
column8: a waste licence in certain circumstances.

column1: LEX-FAOC165309;"Chittagong Hill Tracts Treaty
column2: 1997.";"The Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) peace accord was signed on December 2
column3: 1997 in Dhaka at the Prime Minister's office between the government and the Parbatya Chattagram Jana Sanghati Samity (PCJSS). However
column4: some hill tribe sects and organisations have rejected the accord. Both sides
column5: considering CHT as Tribal Populated Region
column6: recognised the necessity for protection of the character of this region and for overall development of it. Both sides
column7: in accordance with the decisions and responsibilities state in these paragraphs under this agreement
column8: determined to make
column9: change
column10: amend and add concerned rules and procedures as per laws/rules. With an aim to observe the implementation process of this agreement an Implementation Committee shall be formed with the persons stated below A member to be nominated by the Prime Minister - Convenor Chairman of the Task Force formed under this agreement - Member President of the Parbattya Chattagram Jana Samhati Samiti - Member. The following subjects shall be functions and responsibilities of the Hill District Council: Land and land management Police (local) Tribal law and social justice Youth welfare Environment preservation and development Local tourism Improvement trust and other local govt organisations except Pourasabha and Union Councils Licencing for local trade and business Proper utilisation of water resources of rivulets
column11: canals
column12: ponds except Kaptai lake and irrigation Preservation of death
column13: birth and other statistics Money lending and trade Jhum cultivation.

column1: LEX-FAOC163208;"Decree No. 9 of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environmental Protection validating the Instruction on the modalities of performance of local environmental monitoring by legal persons performing economic and other activities causing negative environmental impact
column2: including ecologically hazardous activities.";"This Decree establishes the modalities of performance of local environmental monitoring by legal persons performing economic and other activities causing negative environmental impact
column3: including ecologically hazardous activities. Local environmental monitoring shall be integral part of the National environmental monitoring system. Local environmental monitoring shall include: (a) emissions to the atmospheric air by stationary sources; (b) effluent waste water discharge to surface waterbodies; (c) groundwater in areas of potential pollution; and (d) soil in areas of potential pollution.

column1: LEX-FAOC153362;"Common Agricultural Policy Basic Payment and Support Schemes (Wales) Regulations 2015 (W.S.I. No. 1252 (W. 84) of 2015).";"These Regulations make provision in Wales for the administration of Regulation (EU) No. 1307/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing rules for direct payments to farmers under support schemes within the framework of the common agricultural policy and some associated Regulations. They specify the minimum eligible area of a holding in respect of which direct payments may be granted to a farmer and the activities a farmer must carry out in order to maintain an agricultural area in a state suitable for grazing or cultivation. They also
column2: among other things: set out how payment entitlements under the basic payment scheme will be allocated and fixes the date on which the number of eligible hectares must be at the disposal of farmers; set out how payment entitlements under the basic payment scheme may be transferred via sale or lease and makes provision for the period within which a transferor must notify the Welsh Ministers of a transfer of payment entitlements; set out those non-agricultural activities which are permitted on an agricultural area for a limited period. Regulations 14 to 16 make provision relating to the “greening” component of direct payments
column3: linking payments to agricultural practices beneficial for the climate and environment. Regulation 14 sets out the period to be taken into account for the purposes of determining whether crop diversification requirements have been met. Regulation 15 provides for the designation of permanent grasslands which are environmentally sensitive. Regulation 16 sets out the five areas which are to be Ecological Focus Areas (“EFAs”) and details the scope of the EFAs relating to land lying fallow
column4: landscape features
column5: areas of short rotation coppice
column6: afforested areas and areas with nitrogen fixing crops.

column5: including land plots.

column1: LEX-FAOC122137;"Agriculture
column2: Fisheries and Food Authority Act
column3: 2013 (No. 13 of 2013).";"This Act provides for the establishment of the Agriculture
column4: Fisheries and Food Authority
column5: the administration of matters of agriculture and the preservation
column6: utilization and development of agricultural land and related matters.""Agriculture"" in this Act means cultivation of land and the use of land and water for any purpose of husbandry
column7: aquaculture and food production and includes: (a) cultivation of crops and horticultural practice within the meaning of the Crops Act; (b) breeding of aquatic animals and plants in the Kenya fishery waters and sea ranching and fish farming in the sea as provided for in the Fisheries Act; (c) the use of land
column8: meadow land
column9: market gardens or nursery grounds: (d) fish harvesting within the meaning of the Fisheries Act; and (e) the use of land for agroforestry
column10: when that use is ancillary to the use of land for other agricultural purposes; (f) transgenic and microbial formulations for use and application in agricultural systems. The Authority is established as a body corporate and shall be the successor to the institutions established by the Acts repealed under section 41 this Act
column11: i.e. the Crops Act
column12: the Livestock Act and Fisheries Act. It shall
column13: in consultation with the county governments
column14: among other things: (a) administer the Crops Act and the Fisheries Act; (b) promote best practices in
column15: and regulate
column16: the production
column17: processing
column18: marketing
column19: grading
column20: storage
column21: collection
column22: transportation and warehousing of agricultural and aquatic products excluding livestock products; (c) collect data and maintain a database on agricultural and aquatic products excluding livestock products; (d) determine the research priorities in agriculture and aquaculture; (e) advise the national government and the county governments on agricultural and aquatic levies; (f) carry out such other functions as may be assigned to it by this Act
column23: the Crops Act
column24: the Fisheries Act and any written law.The Cabinet Secretary shall
column25: on the advice of the Authority
column26: and in consultation with the National Land Commission
column27: provide general guidelines applicable in respect of any category of agricultural land. These land development guidelines shall be implemented by the respective county governments. In a like manner
column28: the Cabinet Secretary shall make general rules for the preservation
column29: utilization and development of agricultural land and aquatic resources and prescribe national guidelines for soil conservation. The Cabinet Secretary may also declare a plant to be a noxious or invasive weed in any area.Each county government shall within its area of jurisdiction be responsible
column30: for agricultural matters in accordance with Part 2 of Fourth Schedule to the Constitution. They shall keep a register of land development orders and land preservation orders
column31: which they may issue under this Act. The Act also provides for participation by farmers.

column1: LEX-FAOC035693;"Native Lands Ordinance.";"An Ordinance to provide for title and registration of rights in native land.The Act consists of 64 sections divided into 9 Parts: Preliminary (I); Titles to native land (II); Alienation (III); The Land Court (IV); Lands Code (V); Leases (VI); Survey (VII); Penalties (VIII); General (IX).Section 4 concerns indefeasibility of title of native title subject to specified conditions. Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance native land shall not be alienated
column2: whether by sale
column3: gift
column4: lease or otherwise
column5: to a person who is not a native (sect. 5). There is established within the area of authority of each local government council a land court and each court shall have a registrar. A Lands Courts Appeals Panel is established for appeal in first instance on judgements issued by land courts. The court shall hear and adjudicate in accordance with the provisions of the Lands Code or
column6: where the Code is not applicable
column7: the local customary law
column8: all cases concerning land
column9: land boundaries and transfers of titles to native land registered in the registers of native lands and any disputes concerning the possession and utilisation of native land. The court shall adjudicate on all cases brought before it concerning the determination of native customary fishing rights. Part VI concerns approval
column10: registration
column11: transfer
column12: etc. of native leases.

column3: o por expropiación
column4: las tierras o mejoras de propiedad de los particulares

column6: para dar cumplimiento a los objetivos señalados en la Ley Nº 160 de 1994 y a los fines de utilidad pública e interés social contemplados por esa misma Ley. El INCORA será el ejecutor exclusivo de los programas y actividades de adquisición de tierras para los propósitos de reforma agraria

column8: criterios y prioridades que establezcan el Ministerio de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural

column1: LEX-FAOC012424;"Rating Act 1967 (No. 24 of 1967).";"Subject to this Act
column2: the local authority may assess and levy a general rate upon all immovable property. The rate assessed shall be subject to the approval of the Minister for Local Administration. As a general principle
column3: each rate shall be made
column4: levied and assessed partly on the valuation of the land without improvements and partly on the value of the improvements
column5: unless the local authority determines that any rate shall be made
column6: levied and assessed on the valuation of the land only or the improvements only. Exemptions from rates shall be made for immovable property: (a) vested in the Government; or (b) used exclusively throughout the year for public purposes. The local authority shall prepare and maintain an up-to-date list of all immovable property which is exempted from the payment of rates. For the purpose of assessing the rates
column7: the local authority shall valuate all immovable property within its area. The valuation shall be entrusted to a valuer
column8: who shall prepare a draft valuation roll containing: (a) the description of the land: (b) the area of the land; (c) the situation of the land; (d) the name of the owner; (e) the nature of the use of the land and improvements; (f) the value of the land without improvements; (g) the value of improvements; (h) the total improved value of the land; (i) a reference to any agricultural certificate granted in the terms of section 13
column9: according to which the valuer may declare a property
column10: used ""bona fide"" and exclusively for agricultural purposes
column11: as being an agricultural land. The basis of the valuation shall be deemed the ordinary market price of the land.Further provisions concern inter alia: (a) the power of the valuer to entry and carry on inspections on the land; (b) the certification of valuation to owners; (c) the appointment of a valuation court by the Minister; (d) the hearing of objections; (e) the certification of valuation roll; (f) the purchase and inspection of valuation roll; (g) interim valuations. The treasurer shall be the collector of rates and
column12: subject to section 32
column13: may
column14: under that title
column15: sue for and recover all rates which are due and payable to the local authority. A penalty calculated according to the provisions of section 30 shall be added in respect of any rate remaining unpaid after the expiry of two months form the date on which such rate became due and payable. Sections 31 and 32 deal with the recovery of rates and the legal proceedings for recovery of rates. The registration of any transfer of immovable property is subject to the submission of a certificate
column16: signed by the town clerk or treasurer
column17: declaring that all rates in respect thereof have been paid. The certificate shall also cover any amount owing to the local authority by the owner by way of any fees or charges which may be payable
column18: under any other law
column19: in respect of the property. Miscellaneous provisions regard the following: returns of transfers of property; serving of notices and documents; evidence; recovery of cost of valuation; penalties for offences.The Act is completed by one Schedule
column20: which is divided into four Parts. Part I contains a list of the areas to which the Act applies; Parts II
column21: III and IV contain
column22: respectively
column23: model forms of the declaration of the valuer
column24: the certification of valuer and the certificate of the valuation court.

No. 17 of 2008).";"These Regulations amend the Planning (Environmental Impact Assessment) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1999 to effect to Article 3 of Directive 2003/35/EC of the European Parliament of the Council of 26 May in so far as it affects public participation in the decision-making process for applications and appeals relating to development for which environmental impact assessment is required. They
column2: among other things: (a) set out the circumstances in which the Department of the Environment may direct that a particular proposed development is exempted from the application of these Regulations and must notify persons and environmental organizations likely to be affected by
column3: or having an interest in
column4: the applications; (b) extend the requirements in relation to any other information provided by the applicant relating to the environmental statement; extend the public information requirements in respect of projects located within Northern Ireland that are likely to have significant effects on the environment of another EEA state
column5: and for projects in another EEA state that are likely to have significant effects on the environment in Northern Ireland.

column1: LEX-FAOC138250;"Spatial Planning and Land Use Management Act
column2: 2013 (No. 16 of 2013).";"This Act concerns spatial planning in South Africa at national and local level. It provides for a uniform
column3: effective and comprehensive system of spatial planning and land use management and development
column4: and for the sustainable and efficient use of land. The Act consists of 62 sections divided into seven Chapters: Introductory Provisions (1); Development Principles and Norms and Standards (2); Intergovernmental Support (3); Spatial Development Frameworks (4); Land Use Management (5); Land Development Management (6); General Provisions (7). The Act is completed by three Schedules.The Act defines spatial planning at municipal and provincial level and defines general principles
column5: which shall apply to all organs of state and other authorities responsible for the implementation of legislation regulating the use and development of land. Those principles concern
column6: among other things management of prime and unique agricultural land and protection of consistency of land use measures with environmental protection. The Minister must
column7: after consultation with organs of state in the provincial and local spheres of government
column8: prescribe norms and standards for land use management and land development and shall provide support and assistance to local authorities in the performance of land use management functions. The national and provincial spheres of government and each municipality must prepare spatial development frameworks as determined by this Act. A municipality must
column9: after public consultation
column10: adopt a single land use scheme and may pass by-laws aimed at enforcing its land use scheme.Except as provided in this Act
column11: all land development applications must be submitted to a municipality as the authority of first instance. A municipality must
column12: in order to determine land use and development applications within its municipal area
column13: establish a Municipal Planning Tribunal. The registration of any property resulting from a land development application may not be performed unless the municipality certifies that all the requirements and conditions for the approval have been complied with.

column1: LEX-FAOC149122;"Decreto Supremo Nº 014/15/MINAGRI - Precisa disposiciones que regulan otorgamiento de tierras eriazas para pequeña agricultura y establece disposiciones complementarias para reuso de aguas residuales tratadas en tierras eriazas.";"El presente Decreto Supremo tiene por objeto precisar disposiciones que regulan otorgamiento de tierras eriazas de dominio del Estado con aptitud agropecuaria para el desarrollo de pequeña agricultura
column2: a fin de asegurar su correcta aplicación; así como establecer disposiciones complementarias que permitan el reuso de aguas residuales tratadas en tierras eriazas
column3: que se otorguen al amparo del Reglamento en materia del otorgamiento de tierras eriazas de la Ley N° 26505
column4: de la inversión privada en el desarrollo de las actividades económicas en las tierras del territorio nacional y de las comunidades campesinas y nativas.En los procedimientos de otorgamiento de tierras eriazas para pequeña agricultura
column5: es obligatorio contar con el documento que acredite la disponibilidad del recurso hídrico
column6: en el que se identifique la fuente natural de agua y la cantidad de agua de libre disposición que permita atender nuevas demandas de agua. La disponibilidad hídrica es determinada por la Autoridad Nacional del Agua (ANA)
column7: a través de las Autoridades Administrativas del Agua. Por lo tanto
column8: no procede el otorgamiento de tierras eriazas para pequeña agricultura en aquellos ámbitos territoriales en los que no exista disponibilidad del recurso hídrico. Igualmente
column9: no procede el otorgamiento en aquellas zonas en las que se haya declarado el agotamiento de la fuente natural de agua
column10: así como en las zonas de protección o declaradas en veda. Tales prohibiciones no serán aplicables a aquellos casos en los que se prevea el reuso de aguas residuales tratadas. En estos casos
column11: el solicitante deberá contar con la autorización que le permita el reuso de aguas residuales tratadas
column12: o la suscripción de contratos con municipalidades o entidades prestadoras de servicios de saneamiento
column13: o con personas jurídicas que cuentan con contratos suscritos con estas entidades sobre reuso de aguas residuales tratadas
column14: y la conformidad de interconexión de la infraestructura para dicho reuso de aguas otorgado por el titular del sistema de tratamiento.

column1: LEX-FAOC149708;"National Action Plan for Gender Equality (NAP-GE).";"The National Action Plan for Gender Equality (NAP-GE) is a sectoral national action plan in force for the period of 2006-2010. Its main goal is to contribute towards the attainment of equality between men and women
column2: in social
column3: political and economic development.The Action Plan aims to enhance women's and girls’ economic empowerment. For implementing this general objective the following specific objectives are contemplated: (1) promoting women’s participation in developing economic policies and managing the economy; (2) enhancing rural women’s equal access to and control over productive resources and services (land
column4: oxen
column5: extension
column6: credit) in order to make them food secure and come out of the poverty trap; (3) improving the lives of pastoral women; (4) enhancing urban women's and disabled women’s access to and control over economic resources and services (land
column7: credit
column8: employment
column9: training); (5) reducing women’s workload; and (6) providing special social and economic safety and security to poor urban and rural as well as disabled women.Among the specific objectives noted above
column10: the objective two could be singled out. It provides for the following activities: (1) improving property right laws with more security
column11: flexibility and transferability; (2) identifying
column12: developing
column13: and disseminating technologies that meet the special needs of women and contribute to reducing their poverty; (3) developing alternative livelihoods for poor and disabled women so that they get dependable income sources and are less susceptible to economic shocks; (4) providing poor women and women with disabilities with access to savings and credit mechanisms and institutions; (5) applying special considerations to enable poor women farmers’ access to extension services
column14: increasing women extension workers
column15: and promoting multi-package extension program responsive to area-specific production needs of rural poor women; and (6) establishing/strengthening micro-enterprises
column16: new small businesses
column17: cooperative enterprises
column18: and other institutions that enhance women’s economic empowerment.For the implementation of objective three above i.e. improving the lives of pastoral women
column19: the following activities are included in the Action Plan: undertake thorough study on the conditions of women in pastoral areas; improve pastoralist women’s access to and control over resources (cattle
column20: cash
column21: and other assets); develop special service packages for pastoral women (extension
column22: education and training
column23: health
column24: credit
column25: and others); and develop projects to reduce workload of pastoral women.Finally
column26: under objective four above
column27: these activities will be carried out: develop gender-sensitive policies and measures to empower women in technical
column28: managerial and entrepreneurial fields; provide poor women and women with disability with entrepreneurial potentials
column29: with access to savings and credit services; provide business services
column31: information and technology
column32: to poor women; and review/amend laws and procedures governing operations of financial institutions to ensure provision of services to women and men on equal basis.Additionally
column33: the Action Plan envisages a general objective to enhance the role and benefits of women in environmental management and protection. This is broken down into the following specific objectives: (1) promote women’s participation and empowerment at all levels; (2) increase women’s access to information
column35: and alternative livelihoods; (3) create strong institutions and institutional mechanisms that guide and support efforts to address gender and environment issues; (4) ensure adequate housing conditions
column37: improved sanitation and fuel to urban and rural women; and (5) develop and implement guidelines on environmental management and women in pastoral areas.

column1: LEX-FAOC149709;"Zambia Vision 2030";"The National Long Term Vision 2030 (Vision 2030) is Zambia's first ever written long-term plan
column2: expressing Zambians’ aspirations by the year 2030. The formulation process utilized both top-down and bottom-up approaches
column3: where various stakeholders at both national and regional level were consulted.The Zambian people’s vision is to become “a prosperous middle income nation by 2030”. By 2030
column4: Zambians
column5: aspire to live in a strong and dynamic middle-income industrial nation that provides opportunities for improving the well being of all
column7: underpinned by the principles of: (i) gender responsive sustainable development
column8: (ii) democracy
column9: (iii) respect for human rights
column10: (iv) good traditional and family values
column11: (v) positive attitude towards work
column12: (vi) peaceful coexistence and
column13: (vii) private-public partnerships.To achieve middle-income status
column14: Zambia’s socio-economic development objectives are: (i) to attain and sustain annual real economic growth rates of between 6 and 10 percent
column15: (i) to attain and maintain a moderate inflation rate of 5 percent
column16: (iii) to decelerate the annual population growth rate from its 2005 rate of 2.9 percent to a rate of less than 1.0 percent over the next 25 years
column17: (iv) to reduce national poverty head count to less than 20 percent of the population and
column18: (v) to reduce income inequalities measured by a Gini coefficient of less than 40
column19: (vi) to provide secure access to safe potable water sources and improved sanitation facilities to 100 percent of the population in both urban and rural areas.In order to eliminate hunger
column20: food insecurity and malnutrition
column21: the government plans a well nourished and health population by 2030. Strategies to be implemented are: (i) develop or advocate policies and programmes that will ensure food and nutrition security
column22: food quality and safety at individual household
column23: community and national level
column24: (ii) prevent and control specific macro and micronutrient deficiencies and promote appropriate diets and lifestyles throughout all stages of human life
column25: (iii) strengthen nutrition care practices for vulnerable groups
column26: including young children
column27: adolescents
column28: women in the reproductive age
column30: and those affected by non communicable diseases like diabetes
column31: hypertension
column34: (iv) develop and sustain human resource capacity in the nutrition sector to meet the growing nutrition demands
column35: and (v) establish and maintain an efficient institutional arrangement and strong nutritional networks
column36: (vi) attainment of 80 percent access to clean water supply to all by 2015 and 100 percent by 2030.In order to make agriculture
column37: forestry and fisheries more productive and sustainable
column38: the sector vision is an efficient
column40: sustainable and export-led agriculture sector that assures food security and increased income by 2030. To achieve this goal
column41: the government plans to: (i) increase agricultural productivity and land under cultivation by 2030
column42: (ii) increase exports of agricultural and agro-processed products by 2030
column43: (iii) preserve the agricultural resource base by 2030
column54: (vii) land being productively exploited for socio-economic development by 2030
column55: and women men and the disabled have equal access to productive land for socio-economic development by 2030.Regarding the reduction of rural poverty
column56: the government plans to sustain full employment by 2030. Strategies to be implemented are: (i) to maintain unemployment rate to below 10 per cent of the total labour force by 2030
column57: (ii) the proportion of the labour force operating in an environment in which labour laws are respected and safeguarded to reach 90 per cent by 2030
column58: (iii) to have an efficient and effective labor market information system in place by 2015
column59: and (iv) to ensure that the minimum wage is commensurate with the prevailing living wage
column60: (v) innovative and productive lifelong education and training for all by 2030. In addition
column61: the government plans to include Gender equity and equality in the socio-economic development process by 2030 through
column63: the following strategies: (i) economically empower women through acquisition and ownership of titled land
column64: (ii) reduce and ultimately eliminate gender imbalances and inadequacies associated with the provision of education
column66: (iii) facilitate and provide economic support to institutions that offer credit facilities to women for land development.

column2: protection
column3: restoration and management of the objects of historical and cultural heritage.";"This Governmental Decree establishes that objects of historical and cultural heritage shall be construction
column4: memorial sites related to historical events in the life of society and development of society and the state
column5: that represent historical
column7: artistic and other value. State management in the sphere of historical and cultural heritage shall be performed by the Government through authorized state institution. The aforesaid institution shall perform the following functions: (a) state registration; (b) establishment of protection and maintenance regime; (c) scientific research; (d) land-use planning; and (e) enforcement of legislation on protection of historical and cultural heritage.

column1: LEX-FAOC161242;"Local Government (Exemption from Building and Land Use Permit) Regulations (GN No. 250 of 2015).";"These Regulations
column2: made by the Minister under sections 117(2A) and 162 of the Local Government Act
column3: exempts a person who intends to carry out a classified trade from applying for a Building and Land Use Permit
column4: provided that the activities in relation to that trade — (a) do not require — (i) the construction or demolition of a building; or (ii) extensive alterations
column5: additions or repairs to an existing building; and (b) do not result in specified nuisances. ""Classified trade"" includes
column7: self-employed manufacturer of food items and retail sale of food.

column1: LEX-FAOC089629;"Bumbuna Watershed Management Authority and the Bumbuna Conservation Area Act (No. 6 of 2008).";"This Act establishes the Bumbuna Watershed Management Authority and constitutes the Bumbuna Conservation Area.The object for which the Authority is established is to promote sustainable land use practices and environmental management in the Bumbuna Watershed
column2: to protect the flora and fauna in the Bumbuna Conservation Area and to protect the Bumbuna reservoir.The Authority shall be a body corporate and be managed by a Board. The functions of the Authority shall include: (a) development and implementation of develop the Bumbuna Watershed Management and Conservation Strategy and Action Plan to address water
column3: land use and agricultural issues and to mitigate negative impacts on wildlife
column4: vegetation and aquatic ecology; (b) management of the Bumbuna Conservation Area in line with national conservation policies; (c) preparation of a detailed inventory and mapping of fauna and flora; and (d) establishment of a detailed biodiversity monitoring programme.The Minister responsible for land shall constitute the Bumbuna Conservation Area. The Authority may by statutory instrument make Regulations as it considers necessary or expedient for giving effect to the provisions of this Act.

column1: LEX-FAOC154064;"Settled Land Act 1884.";"This Act
column2: consisting of 58 sections divided into 15 Parts and completed by one Schedule
column3: establishes measures for facilitating sales
column4: leases
column5: and other disposition of settled land
column7: “settlement” includes “an instrument or instruments which under this Act or the corresponding previous enactments is or are deemed to be or which together constitute a settlement
column8: and a settlement which is deemed to have been made by any person or to be subsisting for the purposes of this Act”
column9: what constitutes a settlement is defined under section 8. The Act defines the rights and powers of tenants for life (sects. 12-29 and Part II)
column10: including mining and building leases
column11: provides for the procedure for the settlement of disputes (sects. 30-37)
column12: regulates investment for land improvements and addresses matters related to the sale and purchase of land. Section 58 of Part XV is repealed.

column1: LEX-FAOC149496;"Decreto Nº 1.071 - Decreto Único Reglamentario del Sector Administrativo Agropecuario
column2: Pesquero y de Desarrollo Rural.";"El presente Decreto
column3: considerando que la racionalización y simplificación del ordenamiento jurídico es una de las principales herramientas para asegurar la eficiencia económica y social del sistema legal y para afianzar la seguridad jurídica
column4: y que constituye una política pública gubernamental la simplificación y compilación orgánica del sistema nacional regulatorio
column5: expide el Decreto Único Reglamentario del Sector Administrativo Agropecuario
column6: Pesquero y de Desarrollo Rural. El Sector Agropecuario
column7: Pesquero y de Desarrollo está integrado por el Ministerio de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural y sus entidades adscritas y vinculadas. El Ministerio de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural tiene a su cargo la orientación
column8: control y evaluación del ejercicio de las funciones de sus entidades adscritas y vinculadas
column9: sin perjuicio de las potestades de decisión que les correspondan
column10: así como de su participación en la formulación de la política
column11: en la elaboración de los programas sectoriales y en la ejecución de los mismos.Son Órganos Sectoriales de Asesoría y Coordinación: 1) la Comisión Nacional de Crédito Agropecuario; 2) el Consejo Nacional de la Reforma Agraria y Desarrollo Rural Campesino; 3) el Consejo Nacional de Secretarías de Agricultura; 4) El Comité Asesor de Política Forestal; 5) el Consejo Nacional de Adecuación de Tierras; 6) la Comisión Nacional de Territorios Indígenas; y 7) el Consejo Asesor de Mercados Mayoristas.Son Fondos Especiales del Sector Agropecuario
column12: Pesquero y de Desarrollo Rural: 1) el Fondo de Fomento Agropecuario; 2) el Fondo Agropecuario de Garantías (FAG); 3) el Fondo de Solidaridad Agropecuaria (FONSA); y 4) el Fondo de Inversiones de Capital de Riesgo.Son entidades adscritas al Ministerio de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural: 1) el Instituto Colombiano Agropecuario (ICA); 2) el Instituto Colombiano de Desarrollo Rural (INCODER); 3) la Unidad Administrativa Especial de Gestión de Restitución de Tierras Despojadas; 4) la Unidad Administrativa Especial Autoridad Nacional de Acuicultura y Pesca (AUNAP); y 5) la Unidad de Planificación de Tierras Rurales
column13: Adecuación de Tierras y usos Agropecuarios (UPRA).Son entidades vinculadas al Ministerio de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural: 1) el Banco Agrario de Colombia S. A. (BANAGRARIO); 2) el Fondo para el Financiamiento del Sector Agropecuario (FINAGRO); 3) los Almacenes Generales de Depósito (ALMAGRARIO S. A.); 4) la Empresa Colombiana de Productos Veterinarios S. A. (VECOL S.A.); 5) los Fondos Ganaderos; 6) las Corporaciones de Abastos en las que la Nación o las entidades descentralizadas del Sector
column14: del orden nacional
column15: posean acciones o hayan efectuado aportes de capital; y 7) la Caja de Compensación Familiar Campesina (COMCAJA).Son corporaciones de participación mixta del Sector Agropecuario

column1: LEX-FAOC152562;"Loi sur la géoinformation (LGéo-VD).";"La présente loi fixe les dispositions d'application de la loi fédérale du 5 octobre 2007 sur la géoinformation (LGéo) et règle le traitement des géodonnées de base relevant du droit cantonal ou communal. L’article 2 établit que sauf dispositions contraires du droit fédéral ou cantonal
column2: la loi régit à l'égard du canton et des communes: a) la saisie
column3: la mise à jour et la gestion de leurs géodonnées de base; b) l'accès aux géodonnées de base et leur utilisation; c) l'introduction et la tenue du cadastre des restrictions de droit public à la propriété foncière; d) la mensuration officielle; e) le financement des tâches mentionnées sous lettres a
column4: b
column5: c et d ci-avant. Elle s'applique également aux autres géodonnées du canton et des communes sous réserve d'exceptions prévues par le droit cantonal ou communal. Le Conseil d'Etat dresse l'inventaire des géodonnées de base de droit cantonal. Lorsqu'elles gèrent des géodonnées de base de droit communal
column6: les communes en dressent l'inventaire dans un catalogue. Le texte comprend 55 articles répartis en 6 chapitres comme suit: Dispositions générales (Ier); Principes (II); Mensuration officielle (III); Financement (IV); Dispositions pénales (V); Dispositions transitoires et finales (VI).

column1: Mis en oeuvre par: Règlement d'application de la loi du 8 mai 2012 sur la géoinformation (RLGéo-VD). (2015-03-02)
Met en oeuvre: Loi fédérale sur la géoinformation (Loi sur la géoinformation
column2: LGéo). column1: LEX-FAOC152563;"Règlement d'application de la loi du 8 mai 2012 sur la géoinformation (RLGéo-VD).";"Le présent règlement a pour objet l'application de la loi du 8 mai 2012 sur la géoinformation. L'annexe 1 concrétise le catalogue des géodonnées de base de droit fédéral en désignant les services dont relèvent la saisie
column2: la mise à jour et la gestion des géodonnées de base de droit fédéral au niveau cantonal. L'annexe 2 contient le catalogue des géodonnées de base de droit cantonal et désigne les services dont relèvent la saisie
column3: la mise à jour et la gestion de ces géodonnées. Le texte comprend 47 articles répartis en10 chapitres comme suit: Dispositions générales (Ier); Registre des bâtiments (II); Exigences qualitatives et techniques (III); Garantie de la disponibilité et archivage (IV); Accès et utilisation (V); Géoservices (VI); Echange de géodonnées entre autorités (VII); Mensuration officielle (VIII); Financement (IX); Dispositions transitoires et finales (X).

column1: LEX-FAOC151913;"Act amending Environment Protection Act.";"This Act lays down some amendments and addenda to Environment Protection Act. In particular it sets out provisions concerning ground surface protection which is based on: (1) rational management; (2) maintaining the environmental
column2: economic
column3: social and cultural rights
column4: including production of food and biomass
column5: storing
column6: filtering and transformation of nutrient substances and water
column7: the basis for the development of life and biodiversity; source of raw materials
column8: reservoir of carbon
column9: collection of geological
column10: geomorphological and archaeological heritage; (3) prevention of pollution substances that cause risks and remediation; (4) maintaining the best condition of the soil by preventing water and wind erosion
column11: decrease of humus content of soil
column12: compacting
column13: salinity through the accumulation of soluble salts in the soil
column14: action that causes acidification; (5) mitigating effects of soil capping; 6) preventing mass movements of the ground and their effects; (7) preventing adverse changes in the natural topography of the ground. Contamination of surface ground is assessed on the basis of of exceeding the permissible content of substances causing the risk in the soil or in the ground.

column1: LEX-FAOC137909;"Property Valuation Act
column2: 2014 (No. 17 of 2014).";"This Act: (a) gives effect to the provisions of the Constitution which provide for land reform and to facilitate land reform through the regulation of the valuation of property; (b) provides for the establishment of the Office of the Valuer-General; (c) provides for the valuation of property that has been identified for purposes of land reform; (d) provides a voluntary valuation service to departments; and (e) provides for the setting of criteria and procedures and the monitoring of valuations.

column1: LEX-FAOC154530;"Regulations of the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region on the administration of rural collective-owned assets.";"These Regulations
column2: consisting of 29 articles
column3: aim to strengthen the management of the assets of the rural collective economic organizations
column4: and protect the legitimate rights and interests of the owners and operators thereof. The assets of the rural collective economic organizations belong to all members of the collective economic organization
column5: which are managed by the collective economic organizations
column6: and whose ownership is protected by law. The ownership and the operating rights of assets of rural collective economic organizations may be separated. The lawful rights and interests of the asset operaters of the collective economic organizations are protected by law. They shall perform the obligations to manage and protect the assets of the collective economic organizations.

column1: LEX-FAOC110560;"Decree No. 77 of the Ministry of Agriculture and Food validating the Instruction on chalking of sour agricultural land.";"This Decree establishes mandatory requirements for chalking of sour agricultural land and shall be applicable to all agricultural organizations producing agricultural commodities. The Instruction consists of 9 Sections: (1) general provisions; (2) agrotechnical requirements; (3) elaboration of design and estimate documentation; (4) quantity of fertilizers; (5) chalking of hayland and grassland; (6) types of chalking fertilizers; (7) quality control and evaluation of chalking of sour agricultural land; (8) registration of chalking fertilizers and of chalked areas; and (9) determination of regularity of chalking.

column1: LEX-FAOC101686;"Regulation on the management of flood risks.";"This Regulation of the Government of the Republic of Slovenia
column2: which is composed of 17 articles and two Annexes
column3: sets out the conditions and restrictions on land use and implementation of activities in areas at risk from flooding and associated erosion of inland waters and the sea. The aims of this Regulation are: (1) to reduce the risk of adverse effects associated with floods
column4: with a view to protecting human health
column5: the environment
column6: economic activities and cultural heritage; (2) to maintain riparian zones required for flood and erosion processes; (3) to ensure environmental objectives in the areas of flood and erosion in accordance with regulations governing environmental protection.

column1: LEX-FAOC149440;"National Land Policy.";"The National Land Policy was adopted by Jamaica in 1997 as a national policy for the land sector. It establishes the framework needed for Jamaica to become more progressive
column2: transparent and modern in its approaches to land and geographic information management systems
column3: land administration and utilization
column4: land resources and environmental management
column5: and land development planning. The goals and objectives of this Policy are to ensure the sustainable
column7: use and management of the country’s natural resources. The policy seeks to enhance the sector with interventions related to land information management systems; land resources and use; land titling
column8: land tenure and access; acquisition
column9: pricing and divestment of government owned-lands; taxation and incentives for property development; environmental and disaster management; legislation; and institutional framework and reform.In particular
column10: the Policy identifies and seeks to ensure the establishment of an effective network and land information management system
column11: the basis for all planning
column12: development
column13: utilization and management and administration of land; affordable and legally secure access to land for the majority; property taxation measures that would allow for the provision of necessary services; incentives for property development; recognition of the disasters to which the country is prone
column14: and the protection and conservation of sensitive and scarce resources
column15: while pursuing development initiatives in an environmentally sound manner; divestment and acquisition procedures and mechanisms
column16: and pricing formulae that are transparent and rational; innovative and more dynamic approaches to land use planning and development; a participatory approach to planning and development with private sector
column17: non-government and community based initiatives to deal with settlements and environmental issues and to implement solutions; effective land management and administration institutions; and a programme of reform for legislation on land.As mentioned
column18: the Policy adresses land tenure and access issues. Regarding this matter
column19: Chapter 4 of the Policy sets out these policies: a) the Government will continue the programme to putting in place programmes and measures to streamline the land titling process
column20: and modernize land registration activities; b) the Government will deal with the issue of family land to determine how this cultural practice can be recognized and dealt with legally. Solutions to be examined include restricted freehold structure
column21: mandatory land registration
column22: possibility of co-heirs leasing the land and in establishing a legal framework in which this type of tenure can be registered.The Policy will seek to incorporate a disaster mitigation component and hazard risk zoning in physical development plans; and to develop local capacity to prepare landslide
column23: seismic zonation
column24: and storm surge maps.
