column1: LEX-FAOC019077;"Land Code of the Republic of Tajikistan.";"The Land Code makes provision for the regulation of ""land relations"" and its purpose is to secure rational use and protection of land
column2: the protection of the environment
column3: and ""the equal development of all forms of economic activity in Tajikistan"" (Preamble). Other laws regulating land relations may be enacted on the basis of this Code.Land is declared to be in exclusive ownership if the State in article 2. National land resources are divided into categories listed in article 3 and including farming lands
column4: lands of national wood reserves
column5: lands of national water reserves
column6: and state land reserves. These categories are stated in the land cadastre
column7: the land use register
column8: in land allocation decisions of executive bodies
column9: and in title deeds. Articles 5 to 8 define lands that fall under the jurisdiction of various national or local authorities: Government of Tajikistan (5); Chief Land Department of the State Land Inspection (6); executive bodies (Hukumats) of regions
column10: cities and districts (7); ""Jamoats"" within the boundaries of rural settlements (8). Subsequent articles define basic notions such as land users (10)
column11: land tenure (12)
column12: land lease (14)
column13: and provide for land registration. Chapter 2 (articles 19 to 21) defines rights and liabilities of land users. Land assignment procedures are outlined in Chapter 3 (arts. 22 to 31). Article 23 concerns assignment of land for agricultural purposes. Chapters 4 to 7 contain provisions relative to payment of rent and fees
column14: termination of tenure relationships
column15: reimbursement of land users and indemnification of agricultural losses
column16: and the settlement of land disputes. Chapters 8 and 9 concern the protection of land by providing rules for (the supervision of) the rational use of land. Chapter 10 provides for the State land cadastre and other land management instruments to control and monitor land use. Chapter 11 is entirely dedicated to farming lands
column17: being all lands used for agriculture. Farming lands are assigned in accordance with article 65
column18: and as far as ""dehkans"" (private farms) are concerned articles 66 to 69. Chapters 12 to 17 concern the use of land for other purposes
column19: including use for protected areas (14)
column20: forest reserves (15)
column21: water resources conservation (16)
column22: and for the ""national reserve"" being land held in reserve (17). The last two Chapters deal with infringement of land legislation and the application of international agreements. (105 articles)

column1: LEX-FAOC048164;"Town and Country Planning Act (Cap. 283).";"The Act consists of 55 sections divided into 9 Parts: Preliminary (I); Town and Country Planning Tribunal (II); Development Plans (III); Procedure for the preparation and submission of development plans and their modification and extension (IV); Permission required for development and subdivision of land (V); Compensation for refusal or conditional grant of planning permission (VI); Acquisition of land (VII); Regional plans (VIII); General (IX).Section 3 defines the sphere of application of the Act. The provisions of this Act
column2: other than those contained in Part VIII
column3: shall not apply to customary areas as defined in the Lands Act: Cap. 184
column4: provided that the President may by Statutory Order apply all or any of the said provisions to any customary area. The local authorities set out in the First Schedule are appointed as the planning authorities for the respective areas described in that Schedule (sect. 5). The Minister may appoint a planning authority for the purposes of preparing a development plan ordered by the Minister under the provisions of section 15 or exercise of such functions as may be delegated to it under the provisions of section 24. There is hereby established under section 6 the Town and Country Planning Tribunal which shall have the jurisdiction
column5: power and authority conferred upon it by this Act and by any Regulation made hereunder. Appeals to the Tribunal shall be made pursuant to section 11. Section 16 regulates the preparation of development plans. The Minister shall
column7: approve a development plan submitted to him in accordance with Part IV
column8: or reject it giving the reasons for such rejection and order a new development plan to be submitted to him within such period as may be specified in the order
column9: or within such longer period as he may agree. Where a town planning scheme or zoning scheme for an area has been approved under the provisions of the former Act
column10: then such scheme shall be deemed to be an approved development plan under this Act for that area. Permission shall be required for any development or subdivision of land as defined in Part V (sect. 22). The Minister may delegate to any planning authority his functions to the grant or refusal of permission (sect. 24). Sections 31 to 33 provide for enforcement of planning control. Where any land is designated under subsection (2) of section sixteen in a development plan or approved development plan as subject to compulsory acquisition by the President or the local authority
column11: the land may be acquired by the President or the local or authority (sect. 40). An owner of any land which is reserved under the provisions of an approved development plan may require acquisition of that land under section 41. The Minister may order the preparation of a regional plan under section 44.

column1: LEX-FAOC008828;"Rural Land Act [Chapter 20:18].";"This Act concerns rural land. The Act consists of 15 sections divided into 4 Parts: Preliminary (I); Acquisition and Alienation of State Land (II); Occupation of Land by Person Other Than Owner Not Involving Subdivision (III); General (IV).Communal land and other specified types of land are excluded from the operation of this Act (sect. 3). Section 5 provides for the acquisition of land by the State; section 6 for the alienation of State land. Land may be leased or alienated to a single individual or to a single corporate body but not to two or more persons jointly without the consent of the appropriate Minister (sect. 8). Private land shall not be leased for cultivation if not properly demarcated (sect. 9). No cultivation on the basis of share-cropping shall be permitted by the owner on land to which this Act applies unless an agreement in writing and approved by the Minister is in place (sect. 10). The Act is completed by a Schedule made under section 12 and listing matters to which the Appropriate Minister shall give consideration in exercising any duty
column2: function or power conferred in Part III.

column1: LEX-FAOC062996;"Rent Restriction Act (Cap. 296).";"This Act provides for the control of increase in rent of such immovable property as set out in section 2 of this Act. For purposes of rent control
column2: the Minister shall
column3: by notice in the Gazette
column4: establish such Rent Tribunals
column5: having jurisdiction in such areas
column6: as he or she may think fit. These courts may assess and fix rent and shall other powers as set out in sections 5 and 6. Any person who fails to comply with any lawful order or decision of the Tribunal shall be punished in accordance with section 7. Against certain decisions of the Rent Tribunal appeal may be lodged with the High Court. The Act further regulates the increase in rent and various other matters relative to rent of immovable property to which the Act applies.

column2: accession

column4: will
column5: or succession: provided

column8: unless such occupancy shall have ripened into title by prescription.

column2: 1990.";"This Law establishes the principles governing property rights in Armenia. The object of property may be
column3: inter alia
column4: land
column5: bowels of the earth
column6: waters (rivers and lakes) and vegetation and animal life (art. 6). Land is given to the citizens of the Republic of Armenia
column7: by property right
column8: for operating an agricultural enterprise
column9: for gardening
column10: for the construction and maintenance of homes as well as other needs provided by law. The order and condition of land allotment
column11: by property right
column12: is determined by the Land Code of the Republic of Armenia (art. 11). (61 articles)

column1: LEX-FAOC153048;"Arrêté n°2014-0229-MEA-SG du 31 janvier 2014 portant création
column2: attributions
column3: composition et modalités de fonctionnement du Comité de pilotage du projet de gestion des ressources naturelles dans le contexte des changements climatiques au Mali.";"Le présent arrêté crée auprès du ministre chargé de l’Environnement un Comité de Pilotage du Projet de Gestion des Ressources naturelles dans le Contexte des Changements climatiques au Mali.Le Comité de Pilotage du Projet de Gestion des Ressources naturelles dans le Contexte des Changements climatiques au Mali a pour attributions: de veiller à la mise en œuvre effective des orientations stratégiques et politiques du projet; de veiller à la cohérence d’ensemble tant des actions du projet entre elles que celles du projet avec les autres projets du secteur de l’environnement; de veiller à l’implication effective de toutes les parties prenantes; de s’assurer que les activités planifiées et mises en œuvre sont conformes aux orientations de la Politique nationale de Protection de l’Environnement; d’examiner et d’approuver les plans annuels de travail et les budgets y afférents; d’examiner et d’approuver les rapports annuels d’activités et financiers; d’approuver les rapports d’audit et d’évaluation externe; de traiter des litiges entre les parties prenantes dans le cadre de l’exécution du projet.

column1: LEX-FAOC129807;"Law amending the Law on privatization of state agricultural land (shortened procedure).";"This Law amends certain provisions (procedural matters) part of the Law on privatization of state agricultural land (Official Gazette of the Republic of Macedonia 87/2013).Changes are part of the amended simplified (shortened) procedural matters aimed to make the Law and its related field more accessible.The adoption of this amending Law will also provide for a longer period for payment of the purchase price for the purchase of agricultural land in state ownership if the selected bidder is an individual.

column1: LEX-FAOC072006;"Loi nº 07-06 relative à la gestion
column2: à la protection et au développement des espaces verts.";"La présente loi a pour objet de définir les règles de gestion
column3: de protection et de développement des espaces verts dans le cadre du développement durable
column4: pour atteindre les objectifs suivants: améliorer le cadre de vie urbain; d’entretenir et d’améliorer la qualité des espaces verts urbains existants; de promouvoir la création d’espaces verts de toute nature; de promouvoir l’extension des espaces verts par rapport aux espaces bâtis; de faire de l’introduction des espaces verts
column5: dans tout projet de construction
column6: une obligation prise en charge par les études urbanistiques et architecturales publiques et privées.

column1: Mis en oeuvre par: Décret exécutif nº 09-67 relatif à la nomenclature des arbres urbains et des arbres d'alignements. (2009-02-07)

Mis en oeuvre par: Décret exécutif nº 09-147 fixant le contenu et les modalités d'élaboration
column2: d'adoption et de mise en oeuvre du plan de gestion des espaces verts. (2009-05-02)

column1: LEX-FAOC019703;"Decreto Nº 2.663 - Reglamenta la Ley Nº 160 de 1994
column2: en lo relacionado con los procedimientos de clarificación de la situación de las tierras desde el punto de vista de la propiedad y de la delimitación.";"El presente Decreto reglamentan los capítulos X y XIV de la Ley Nº 160 de 1994
column3: en lo relativo a los procedimientos de clarificación de la situación de las tierras desde el punto de vista de la propiedad
column4: de delimitación o deslinde de las tierras del dominio de la Nación y los relacionados con los resguardos indígenas y las tierras de las comunidades negras. Dispone que el Instituto Colombiano de la Reforma Agraria (INCORA) adelantará de oficio o a solicitud de los procuradores agrarios
column5: de las comunidades campesinas
column7: o de las entidades públicas correspondientes
column8: los siguientes procedimientos administrativos: 1) de clarificación de la situación de las tierras desde el punto de vista de la propiedad; 2) delimitar o deslindar las tierras pertenecientes a la Nación
column9: de las de propiedad privada de los particulares
column10: y en especial cuando hayan quedado al descubierto por desecación provocada o artificial de lagos
column11: lagunas
column12: ríos
column13: ciénagas o depósitos naturales de agua; 3) deslindar las tierras de propiedad de los resguardos indígenas
column14: y las adjudicadas a las comunidades negras; 4) regular el uso y manejo de los playones y sabanas comunales.

column1: LEX-FAOC117539;"Zambia Development Agency (Amendment) Act
column2: 2009  (No. 5 of 2009).";"This Act amends the Zambia Development Agency Act
column3: 2006 so as to provide with respect to ""industrial parks"" i.e. any area or premises in Zambia that has been declared by the Minister an industrial park under section 18 of the principal Act. Various consequential amendments are made. The Agency shall monitor and evaluate the activities
column4: performance and development of enterprises operating in industrial parks and prescribe and enforce measures
column5: for the business or activity carried out within an industrial park so as to promote the safety and efficiency of its operations. Section 18 also requires the Minister to provide
column7: rules for operation of industrial parks.

column1: LEX-FAOC099406;"Act on Infrastructure for Spatial Information (No. 1331 of 2008).";"This Act establishes rules on electronic spatial data infrastructure operated and made available to the public. It includes metadata
column2: spatial data sets
column3: network services and network technologies
column4: agreements on access and use as well as provision of spatial data sets
column5: coordination and monitoring mechanisms
column6: processes and procedures.This Act contains provisions implementing parts of the European Parliament and Council Directive 2007/2/EC of 14 March 2007 establishing an Infrastructure for Spatial Information in the European Community (INSPIRE).

column1: LEX-FAOC043983;"Rural Land Administration Proclamation of the Federal Government of Ethiopia (No. 89/1997).";"This basic piece of legislation sets out principles and lays the foundations for laws relative to land tenure and administration of rural land are to be enacted by Regional Councils in respect of each Region of Ethiopia and in accordance with the present Proclamation
column2: laws on environmental protection and land utilization policies. (Rural) land is declared to be a common property of the “Nations
column3: Nationalities and Peoples” of Ethiopia and it is prescribed that land shall not be subject to sale or other means of exchange. Article 6 prescribes contents of the laws to be enacted
column4: including matters such as assignment of land rights
column5: demarcation of land
column7: forestry and communal use. Regional governments shall determine rates of land-use fees and royalties on the use of forest resources.

column1: LEX-FAOC156493;"Regional Law No. 814-OZ “On implementation of Land Code of the Russian Federation on the regional territory”.";"This Regional Law establishes that local government shall have the authority to make decision on allotment of land plot to natural person in ownership free of charge or to refuse to do so within fifteen days from the date of submittal of application by the person concerned. Minimum land area of the aforesaid plot of land shall be 0
column2: 10 ha and maximum land area shall be 0
column3: 20 ha.

column1: LEX-FAOC067625;"Land Use Act 1978.";"This Act vests all land comprised in the territory of each State in the Federation in the Governor of that State and requires that such land shall be held in trust and administered for the use and common benefit of all Nigerians in accordance with the provisions of this Act. In each State a Land Use and Allocation Committee shall be established. Such committee shall be responsible for advising the Governor on land management and resettlement issues. The Governor may declare urban areas and land controlled by the military shall be administered separately. The Governor may
column2: in respect of land
column3: whether or not in an urban areas
column4: grant statutory rights of occupancy to any person for all purposes and grant easements appurtenant to statutory rights occupancy. The Governor may waive all or any of the covenant or conditions applying to a right of occupancy. The local government may grant rights of customary occupancy in respect of land to be used for agricultural purposes. The Act further defines rights and duties of occupants and regulates the determination and payment of rents
column5: the alienation and surrender of rights of occupancy
column6: revocation of rights of occupancy and compensation therefore and some other matters of miscellaneous character. It shall be lawful for the Governor to revoke a right of (customary) occupancy for overriding public interest.

column1: LEX-FAOC018613;"Physical Planning Act.";"If the Minister is satisfied that an area should be declared a controlled area or part of an existing controlled area
column2: he may by notice in the Gazette declare that area
column3: a controlled area
column4: or part of a controlled area. No person shall use land in a controlled area otherwise than for a purpose for which it was being used immediately prior to the date as from which the area concerned was or is declared a controlled area or part of a controlled area; or use land
column5: in a controlled area
column6: which at any time after the date of declaration was not used for a purpose contemplated in the said paragraph (a)
column7: or for any other purpose authorized by or under this Act
column8: for a continuous period of two years
column9: except under the authority of a permit and for the purpose and in accordance with the conditions specified therein.

column1: LEX-FAOC138091;"Regional Law No. 131-z “On ensuring fertility of agricultural land”.";"The scope of this Regional Law shall be to ensure fertility of agricultural land by owners
column2: landlords
column3: land tenants and leaseholders. The main arrangements for ensuring soil fertility of agricultural land shall be: (a) promotion of investments directed at improvement of soil fertility of agricultural land; (b) state rate setting in the sphere of ensuring soil fertility of agricultural land; (c) scientific research and practical application the outcome thereof; and (d) monitoring of soil quality and fertility.

column1: LEX-FAOC112447;"Ley Nº 9/1989 - Ley de Valoración del Suelo de la Comunidad Autónoma del País Vasco.";"La presente Ley tiene por objeto establecer una regulación clara de las valoraciones urbanísticas
column2: evidenciando la universalidad de las reglas de valoración según los conceptos de la Ley sobre Régimen del Suelo y Ordenación Urbana
column3: valor inicial y urbanístico
column4: aplicables a todo tipo de situaciones
column5: con independencia tanto del carácter rústico o urbano de los terrenos
column6: como de la existencia o no de figuras de Planeamiento.

column1: LEX-FAOC151433;"Décret n° 2008-0740-PM du 23 avril 2008 fixant le régime des sanctions applicables aux infractions aux règles d'urbanisme.";"Le présent décret fixe le régime des sanctions applicables aux infractions aux règles d'urbanisme.Ces infractions concernent le non-respect des règles et obligations; le non-respect des dispositions des documents de planification urbaine en vigueur ou
column2: à défaut
column3: des règles générales d'urbanisme et de construction; l'occupation ou l'empiétement du domaine public
column4: du domaine privé de l'Etat
column5: ou du domaine des Collectivités Territoriales Décentralisées.

column1: LEX-FAOC151431;"Décret n° 2008/0739/PM du 23 Avril 2008 fixant les règles d'utilisation du sol et de la construction.";"Le présent décret fixe les règles d'utilisation du sol et de la construction. Il organise les actes administratifs relatifs à l'utilisation du sol et à la construction suivants: le Certificat d’Urbanisme; l'Autorisation de Lotir; le Permis d’Implanter; le Permis de Construire; le Permis de démolir; et le Certificat de Conformité. Des arrêtés du Ministre chargé de l'urbanisme préciseront ces différents actes.

column1: LEX-FAOC022605;"Government Decree 157/1999 (XI.3.) Korm. on the amendment of Government Decree 7/1996 (I.18.) Korm. on the acquisition of real estate by foreign nationals.";"This Decree adds a new 1/A Section to the Basic Text in which the following rules are set forth. Contrary to certain provisions of Section 1 of the Basic Text
column2: the acquisition of real estate by a foreign natural person settling in Hungary as an independent entrepreneur must be authorized pursuant to a separate act
column3: if such property is essential for pursuing the business activities for which the foreign natural person settled. No property intended to be acquired for the purpose of a real estate transaction shall be construed as essential for business activities. If a foreign natural person settled in Hungary as an independent entrepreneur has his business licence or entrepreneurial credentials revoked
column4: he shall be obligated to alienate his real property or file a petition with the director of the office in order to retain ownership rights within one year.

column1: LEX-FAOC142823;"Loi n°2004-001 du 1er  juin 2004 relative aux Régions.";"La présente loi détermine les principes généraux relatifs aux Régions.Elle détermine
column2: entre autres les domaines de compétence de la région
column3: notamment l'établissement de schéma régional d'aménagement du territoire (eau et assainissement); l'établissement d'un programme-cadre et/ou plan régional de développement; le cadrage et à la programmation des actions de développement d'envergure régionale en matière d’aménagement hydro agricole
column4: la pêche
column5: l’élevage
column6: la gestion des environnements; la mise en œuvre
column7: à son échelon
column8: d'actions et mesures appropriées en matière de gestion des risques et des catastrophes.En outre
column9: elle institue au profit des régions les droits et taxe sur les produits miniers
column10: agricoles
column11: forestiers
column12: élevage et pêche destinés à la vente locale et à l'exportation.

column1: LEX-FAOC142827;"Loi n°2005-004 du 22 juin 2005 autorisant la ratification de la Convention de Stockholm sur les Polluants Organiques Persistants.";"La présente loi autorise la ratification de la Convention de Stockholm sur les Polluants Organiques Persistants ayant pour objectif de protéger la santé humaine et l’environnement contre les effets des Polluants Organiques Persistants.Pour préserver la pratique de gestion des Polluants Organiques Persistants
column2: il est nécessaire de mettre fin aux rejets et à l’utilisation des POPs ; d’appuyer l’adoption progressive des substances de remplacement moins dangereux ; d’éliminer les anciens stocks et équipement contenant des POPs ; de protéger la santé des personnes
column3: notamment celles des consommateurs et des travailleurs
column4: ainsi que l’environnement
column5: contre les incidences néfastes des produits chimiques et pesticides dangereux.

column1: LEX-FAOC019670;"Protection of Waters and Soil against Pollution Act.";"This Act sets out the basic rules for the protection of surface
column2: ground and coastal sea waters and soil against pollution. Ministries
column3: institutions
column4: public organizations shall perform regular water and soil protection activities. The control on the protection is duty of the Ministry of Environment. The Ministry of Health and Social Affairs shall exercise sanitary control of waters and soil. It may issue standards and regulations after consultation with the Ministry of Environment. International agreements to which Bulgaria is a party are binding on the protection of transboundary waters. Chapter III prescribes the classification of waters in terms of their use. Pollution of waters shall not exceed maximum levels determined by other means of law. This Chapter prohibits also the discharge of waste water into water courses
column5: fisheries and the sea without permission. Chapter IV deals with the protection of soil. Offenders of the provisions of this Act are liable to a fine
column6: in certain cases they must suspend the harmful activity according to Chapter V.

column1: LEX-FAOC155536;"Décret no 2012-995 du 23 août 2012 relatif à l’évaluation environnementale des documents d’urbanisme.";"Le présent décret détermine les évaluations des incidences des documents d’urbanisme sur l’environnement. En effet
column2: les documents d’urbanisme doivent
column3: en raison de leurs incidences sur l’environnement
column4: faire l’objet d’une évaluation environnementale soit de manière systématique
column5: soit après un examen au cas par cas par l’autorité administrative de l’Etat désignée à cet effet. Les documents soumis à cette obligation sont
column7: les directives territoriales d’aménagement et de développement durables (DTADD)
column8: le schéma directeur de la région Ile-de-France (SDRIF)
column9: les schémas de cohérence territoriale (SCOT)
column10: les plans locaux d’urbanisme (PLU) et certaines cartes communales.L’autorité administrative de l’Etat compétente en matière d’environnement peut être le Conseil général de l’environnement et du développement durable (CGEDD)
column11: le préfet de région
column12: le préfet de département ou le préfet de Corse
column13: pour ce qui concerne le plan d’aménagement et de développement durable de Corse. Lorsqu’elle est saisie au titre de la procédure d’examen au cas par cas
column14: elle décide
column15: dans un délai de deux mois
column16: si le document doit faire l’objet d’une évaluation environnementale. Dans tous les cas
column17: elle formule un avis sur l’évaluation environnementale et le projet de document dans les trois mois suivant sa saisine.

column1: LEX-FAOC028855;"Nindagama Lands Act (No. 38 of 1968).";"This Act concerns the owners and related rights of those who are holders of the Nindagama lands in Sri Lanka. The Act abolishes services due from any tenant or holder of any Nindagama land to any proprietor thereof (sect. 2). Section 3 declares every tenant or holder of any Ninagama land as the owner of the land. No holder of the land shall be liable to pay compensation to the proprietor thereof for any loss or damage incurred or suffered by the proprietor by reason of the abolition of the services due by such holders of that land (sect. 4). There are provisions relating to claims for awards to title in respect of Nindagama lands (sect. 7)Section 8 establishes a Nindagama Lands Board charged with implementing this Act. The Board shall deal with references of claims for awards as to title in respect of any Nindagama lands (sect. 19). The Minister may make regulations for the purpose of carrying out and giving effect to the principles and provisions of this Act (sect. 29). Section 31 lists the definitions of major terms used within the Act including 'Nindagama land' and 'tenant'.

column1: LEX-FAOC123694;"National Environmental Management Protected Areas Act
column2: 2003.";"This Act provides for the protection of areas defined by this Act. The objectives of this Act are: (a) to provide
column3: within the framework of national legislation
column4: for the declaration and management of protected areas; (b) to provide for cooperative governance in the declaration and management of protected areas; (c) to effect a national system of protected areas in South Africa as part of a strategy to manage and conserve its biodiversity; (d) to provide for a representative network of protected areas on state land
column5: private land and communal land; (e) to promote sustainable utilization of protected areas for the benefit of people
column6: in a manner that would preserve the ecological character of such areas; and (f) to promote participation of local communities in the management of protected areas
column7: where appropriate.The Act consists of 93 sections divided into 8 Parts: Interpretation
column8: Objectives and Application of Act (1); System of Protected Areas in South Africa (2); Declaration of Protected Areas (3); Management of Protected Areas (4); South African National Parks (5); Acquisition of Rights in or to Land (6); Administration of Act (7); Offences and Penalties (8); Miscellaneous (9).""Biological diversity"" or ""biodiversity"" has the meaning ascribed to it in section 1 of the Biodiversity Act. The system of protected areas in South Africa consists of the following kinds of protected areas: (a) special nature reserves
column9: nature reserves (including wilderness areas) and protected environments; (b) world heritage sites; (d) specially protected forest areas
column10: forest nature reserves and forest wilderness areas declared in terms of the National Forests Act
column11: 1998 (Act No. 84 of 1998); and (e) mountain catchment areas declared in terms of the Mountain Catchment Areas Act
column12: 1970 (Act No. 63 of 1970). Section 7 deals with conflicts with other legislation. The Minister must maintain Register of Protected Areas (sect. 10). The authority for the management of a protected area assigned in terms of section 38 must
column13: within 12 months of the assignment
column14: submit a management plan for the protected area to the Minister or the Executive Council of a province in whose portfolio provincial protected areas in the province fall for approval.

column1: LEX-FAOC135400;"Regulation of the Shanghai Municipality on Urban and Rural Planning.";"This Regulation aims at strengthening the administration on urban and rural planning
column2: arranging the urban and rural spatial distribution in an overall manner
column3: improving the living environment
column4: and promoting an overall
column5: coordinated and sustainable development of urban and rural economy and society.The Regulations provides for the procedures of
column7: approval
column8: amendment and implementation of urban and rural planning. Such contents as the construction-use land scale
column9: land used for infrastructures and public service facilities
column10: land used for water sources and water system
column11: basic farmlands and afforestation
column12: environmental protection
column13: protection of natural and historical heritage
column14: or the requirements of disaster prevention and mitigation
column15: shall be the compulsory contents of the urban comprehensive planning (Article 20). Special planning involving the spatial arrangement of urban and rural areas shall be organized by relevant municipal professional management departments
column16: and shall be integrated into the corresponding urban and rural planning upon approval. The building permit shall be obtained by the development entity where the construction is conducted on state-owned land. The village construction planning permit shall be obtained in case of individual housing construction by villagers on collectively-owned lands.In addition
column17: the Regulations provides for the supervision and inspection of urban and rural plans and for legal liabilities.

column1: LEX-FAOC149849;"Nitrates Action Programme (Amendment) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2015 (S.R. No. 369 of 2015).";"These Regulations amend the Nitrates Action Programme Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2014 in regard to penalties and the measures concerning land management and record keeping. Regulation 22 is amended to include all crops other than grass and use of appropriate measures when a subsequent crop cannot be sown (measures to prevent erosion of the soil). Regulation 23 is amended to remove restrictions applying only to late harvested crops. Regulation 30 is amended to make non-compliance with Regulations 22 and 24 an offence without a reasonable excuse.

column1: LEX-FAOC083199;"Decreto Ley Nº 6.072/08 - Ley del Régimen Prestacional de Vivienda y Hábitat.";"El presente Decreto Ley tiene por objeto regular el Régimen Prestacional de Vivienda y Hábitat

column1: LEX-FAOC098046;"Regulation on basic surveying and mapping.";"This Regulation aims at strengthening the administration of basic surveying and mapping
column2: regulating the basic surveying and mapping activities and ensuring that the basic surveying and mapping cause serve the construction of national economy
column3: the building-up of national defence as well as the social development.The surveying and mapping administrative department of the State Council shall organize the formulation of the national basic surveying and mapping plan
column4: and organize its implementation.The Regulation further provides for: the organization of the execution of basic surveying and mapping projects; the update and utilization of basic surveying and mapping outcomes; legal liabilities; etc.

column1: LEX-FAOC043670;"Surveying Act 2002.";"This Act consists of 40 sections and is divided into seven Parts: Preliminary; Public surveys; Registration of surveyors; Entry to land for survey purposes; Offences; The Board of Surveying and Spatial Information and Miscellaneous. The Act repeals the Surveyors Act 1929 and related instruments and makes consequential amendments to other Acts. The Act provides for the constitution and functions of the Board of Surveyors and Spatial Information. The Board is responsible for the registration of surveyors
column2: the investigation of surveyors' registration and licensing schemes
column3: the investigation of complaints against registered surveyors and the taking of disciplinary action against registered surveyors.

column1: LEX-FAOC080661;"Ministerial Decree No. 174 validating the Regulation on water protection zones of water reservoirs and other waterbodies
column2: rivers
column3: main channels
column4: manifolds
column5: and also of supply sources of potable water for residential use
column6: sources of medicinal and recreational water uses.";"This Ministerial Decree regulates the establishment of water protection and sanitary protection zones and the modalities of economic activity therein for the purpose of prevention of freshwater pollution
column7: littering and exhaustion of water resources. Water protection areas and coastal belts shall be created around water reservoirs and other waterbodies
column8: and also around rivers
column9: main channels and manifolds while sanitary protection areas shall be created around the sources of potable water supply
column10: sources of mineral and medicinal water. Water conservation arrangements shall be composed of: (a) establishment of water protection zones and rules of economic activity therein; and (b) engineering
column11: amelioration
column12: sanitary and other technical arrangements. Land included in water protection zone shall not be expropriated from their owners but shall be used in accordance with the present Ministerial Decree. Breadth of water protection zones shall be established in accordance with the following criteria: (a) 300-500 metres around big water reservoirs and other waterbodies (capacity of 1
column13: 1 to 10 cubic kilometres); (b) 200-300 metres around medium water reservoirs and other waterbodies (capacity of 0
column14: 6 to 1 cubic kilometre); (c) 100-200 metres around small water reservoirs and other waterbodies (capacity of 0
column15: 2 to 0
column16: 5 cubic kilometres); and (d) up to 100 metres around very small water reservoirs and waterbodies (capacity less that 0
column17: 1 cubic kilometres).

column1: LEX-FAOC026217;"Regulation No. 26/93 approving the Regional Land Use Planning within the territory of Alentejo.";"This Regulation approves the Regional Land Use Planning within the territory of Alentejo. It consists of 5 chapters establishing the requirements to be met in order to carry out the said Regional zone programme (called PROTALI. 1). The aim of this programme is: a) regulate land use and transformation with its rational sustainable exploitation; b) regulate building construction and preserve natural heritage; c) draw-up regional land use plans; d) land management
column2: etc. PROTALI shall be enforced for 10 years.

column1: LEX-FAOC014481;"Countryside Stewardship Regulations 1998 (No. 1327 of 1998).";"These Regulations
column2: make provision supplementing Council Regulation (EC) No. 2078/92
column3: as amended by Commission Regulation (EC) No. 2772/95 which was in turn amended by Commission Regulation (EC) No. 1962/96 on agricultural methods compatible with the requirements of the protection of the environment and the maintenance of the countryside. They provide for payments of grant to be made at any time during or after the agreement year to any person who enters a stewardship agreement with the Minister requiring him to carry out an activity which is conducive to a specified purpose (as defined in reg. 3) on land in which he has an interest (regs. 4 and 5). Schedule 1 specifies activities
column4: which can be included in a stewardship agreement. Such agreement may be either a standard agreement or a special project agreement (reg. 4). These Regulations introduce provisions for the payment of grant in relation to arable farmland in specific areas of England. They also provide for the payment of grant to any person who entered a stewardship agreement with the Countryside Commission provided that the Minister has assumed liability for that agreement.

column1: LEX-FAOC151052;"Great Green Wall for the Sahara and Sahel Initiative - National Strategic Action Plan.";"The Great Green Wall for the Sahara and Sahel Initiative - National Strategic Action Plan is a national sectoral action plan of Nigeria. It applies to the period of 2012-2017. Its main goal is improving the well-being of the affected people and reducing their vulnerability to climate change through improved use of land and other natural resources for sustainable development and support to climate resilient infrastructure.The Action Plan
column2: among others
column3: treats the issue of food security. In this area
column4: it provides for improvement of the management of land resources and their sustainable use. More specifically
column5: the relevant programmes and activities will focus on identifying proven sustainable land management practices in the sub-region and up-scaling best practices that will contribute to sustainable ecosystem-based integrated land management in areas under threat of land degradation
column7: enhanced food security and improved rural livelihoods.The Action Plan also promotes improvement of critical infrastructure for enhanced and sustainable socio-economic development and environmental sustainability. In particular
column8: it notes that investment in core physical infrastructure broadly comprising roads
column9: transport systems
column10: communications
column11: energy and water supply
column12: housing
column13: environmental conservation structures
column14: including parks and forestry can
column15: among others
column16: contribute significantly to sustainable development and management of natural resources in dryland areas of Nigeria
column17: which contain vast resources
column18: biodiversity and watersheds with potential for agriculture
column19: fishing and energy generation.One of the objectives of the abovementioned goal of the Action Plan is to achieve sustainable management of natural resources and to make agriculture
column20: in its broadest sense
column21: the main lever for rural development
column22: economic and social growth. Specifically
column23: this will entail among others restoring the production capacity of existing forest plantations and establishment of additional ones
column24: and development of good governance models of locally based sustainable forest management and promoting efficient management of water and land resources for the optimization of the benefits
column25: mitigation of floods
column26: and reduction of conflicts.Further
column27: one of the policy pillars of the document focuses on the development of basic socio-economic infrastructures in the affected areas. For this
column28: public sector investment in rural roads
column29: health care facilities and educational institutions will be pursued in partnership with the private sector. Other project activities will focus on improving access to drinkable water
column31: recreational facilities
column32: and electricity and communication services. Moreover
column33: another policy pillar of the document encourages private sector operators to invest in the huge economic potentials of natural resources of the region to generate green jobs
column34: ensure environmental sustainability and derive economic benefits through public-private partnership. Emphasis will be in the area of innovative mechanisms for private sector financing of sustainable land management
column35: and biomass- based resources for renewable energy sources and environmental protection
column36: including for example provision of land
column38: one of the key objectives of the document is to fight desertification. To this end it provides for enabling policy
column39: legal and institutional framework for sustainable land management and desertification control. Specifically
column40: it promotes sustainable financing for desertification control focusing on issues of developing a strategic resource mobilization approach and putting in place a Desertification Control Fund that would be facilitated and used by all stakeholders
column42: in the country to address key desertification and land degradation challenges
column43: as well as exploring the opportunities for development while combating desertification. Moreover
column44: the document also provides for Integrated Water Resources Management. This programme among others envisages sustainable water resources management for flood mitigation
column46: pollution control and conflict reduction as well as water harvesting for afforestation and agricultural development. Finally
column47: the Action Plan also targets at establishing early warning mechanisms. Specifically
column48: it will promote creation of a center for drought prediction and early warning that forms part of regional and global networks and will establish Ecological and Environmental Observatory Centres that will compliment those in Niger Republic for the monitoring of land degradation or improvement.The action projects of the Action Plan are expected to be implemented through government organizations in active participation with the local communities. Consequently
column50: State and Local Governments of Nigeria
column52: are the principal partners in the implementation.

column1: LEX-FAOC025565;"Range Regulation (B.C. Reg.199/00).";"This regulation enacts the Range Act
column2: and applies to Crown range. It is divided into 13 sections
column3: and deals with applications for a licence
column4: grazing permit or hay cutting permit. Section 3 outlines the procedure for the advertisement of licences and permits
column5: by the district manager
column6: acting under section 10 (2) of the Act. The content of an application for licence or permit is set out in section 4. Reference is made to competition rules in section 5. When the minister decides to offer a licence or a grazing or hay cutting permit for public competition
column7: he must notify every eligible person who has applied before
column8: and mail a copy of the notification to the secretary of the livestock association for the locality where the licence or permit will be exercised. Otherwise the district manager may
column9: without accepting applications from other persons
column10: make a direct award
column11: under section 6. Section 7 outlines agreements for use of private range lands
column12: and sections 8 to 11 deal with various fees. Section 12 deals with Transfers of licences or permits
column13: and finally section 13 lists various range districts.

column1: Implements: Range Act ([RSBC 1996] Chapter 396). (2004-01-31)

Repealed by: Range Regulation (B.C. Reg.116/2005). column1: LEX-FAOC128992;"Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Holding Act 2013.";"The Act
column2: consisting of 11 Parts and 1 Schedule
column3: divided into 165 Sections
column4: establishes the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Holding Act. The main object of this Act is: (a) to provide a framework for identifying and satisfying entitlements to grants of leases that are outstanding under the 1985 Land Holding Act
column5: including by dealing with practical obstacles to satisfying the entitlements; and (b) to resolve boundary problems affecting particular 1985 Act granted leases; and (c) to the extent practicable
column6: to apply the Aboriginal Land Act 1991 or the Torres Strait Islander Land Act 1991 to both 1985 Act granted leases and new Act granted leases. The Act is divided as follows: Part 1 Preliminary; Part 2 Transition from 1985 Land Holding Act to this Act; Part 3 Lease entitlements; Part 4 Identification of practical obstacles; Part 5 Grants of leases to satisfy lease entitlements; Part 6 Boundary relocations for particular 1985 Act granted leases; Part 7 Ownership of structural improvements; Part 8 Conditions and requirements applying to leases; Part 9 Application of provisions of ALA or TSILA; Part 10 Miscellaneous; Part 11 Repeal and transitional provisions; Schedule 1 Amendment of Acts.

column1: LEX-FAOC149936;"Regional Law No. 61-rz “On Civic Chamber”.";"This Regional Law establishes that Civic Chamber must ensure coordination between citizens
column2: social associations
column3: state bodies and local government
column4: promotion of civil society institutions
column5: and consideration of the interests of the population in the process of elaboration and realization of state policy
column6: protection of rights and freedoms of citizens. Civic Chamber shall be set up to ensure open and transparent discussion of the most important problems of social development
column7: promotion of civil society institutions and democratic principles of the functioning of state bodies. Civic Chamber shall perform the following tasks: (a) involvement of citizens and associations thereof into formation and implementation of state policy; (b) support of civil initiatives aimed at realization of the constitutional rights of citizens; (c) performance of public expertise of federal legislation of joint competence (federal and regional); (d) exercise of public control over local government bodies; (e) advancement of civil initiatives and elaboration of programs for the development of civil society.

column1: Enmienda: Resolución Nº 056/10/VIVIENDA - Norma para determinar los valores unitarios oficiales de terrenos urbanos a nivel nacional. (2010-03-23)

column1: LEX-FAOC103794;"European Communities (Good Agricultural Practice for Protection of Waters) Regulations 2010 (S.I. No. 610 of 2010).";"These Regulations provide
column2: for purposes of implementation of the give effect to Irelands Second Nitrates Action Programme
column3: rules relative to good agricultural practice to protect waters against pollution from agricultural sources and prescribe measures for these purposes
column4: including: periods when land application of fertilizers is prohibited; limits on the land application of fertilizers; storage requirements for livestock manure; and monitoring of the effectiveness of the measures in terms of agricultural practice and impact on water quality. They also concern minimization and storage of soiled water and ploughing and the use of non-selective herbicides.

column1: LEX-FAOC147670;"Règlement n°11/07-UEAC-144-CM-15 du 19 mars 2007 portant création
column2: composition et fonctionnement du Comité de Pesticides d'Afrique Centrale (CPAC)..";"Le présent règlement crée et fixe les règles de composition et de fonctionnement du Comité de Pesticides d'Afrique Centrale (CPAC) chargé d’aider les pays membres à établir des mesures phytosanitaires compatibles avec les normes internationales et à leur permettre de se protéger contre les risques découlant de l'importation incontrôlée des produits chimiques et de leur mauvaise utilisation. Les pesticides ayant obtenu une Autorisation de mise sur le marché ou une Autorisation Provisoire de Vente (APV) portent un numéro de série.Pour atteindre ces objectifs
column3: le CPAC comprend deux Experts de chaque État Membre: membres statutaires; quatre scientifiques Africains: experts; un Secrétaire Permanent : membre/rapporteur; un Représentant du CPI: membre associé; un Représentant de la CEMAC: membre associé; un Représentant de la CEBEVIRHA: membre associé; un Représentant de la CEEAC: Observateur; un Représentant du Comité Sahélien des Pesticides: Observateur; un Représentant de la FAO: observateur; et un Représentant de l'OMS: observateur. Un Règlement intérieur du Comité précise les modalités d'application des dispositions du présent Règlement.

column1: Mis en oeuvre par: Règlement n°09 /12-UEAC-CPAC-CM-23 du 22 juillet 2012 portant organisation et fonctionnement du Comité Inter-Etats des Pesticides d'Afrique Centrale (CPAC). (2012-07-23)

Mis en oeuvre par: Règlement n°09 /12-UEAC-CPAC-CM-23 du 22 juillet 2012 portant organisation et fonctionnement du Comité Inter-Etats des Pesticides d'Afrique Centrale (CPAC). column1: LEX-FAOC102222;"Agricultural Land Act (No. 191 of 2009).";"This Act promotes sustainable development and management of agricultural land in regards to the preservation of environmental and landscape values. All agricultural land in rural and urban areas listed with farming obligation
column2: must be used for agricultural purposes. The Minister for Food
column3: Agriculture and Fisheries shall determine which plant species are considered unfitted due to risk of crops damaging. Owners or operators of agricultural lands shall keep their land free from trees and shrubs.

column1: LEX-FAOC152152;"Acquisition of Land Regulation 2014.";"This Regulation provides for the implementation of the Acquisition of Land Act 1967 by prescribing the fees applicable under section 9 of the Act. The fee payable for an application under section 9 of the Act is— (a) if the application relates to only 1 parcel of land—$173.70; or (b) if the application relates to more than 1 parcel of land—$173.70 plus $51.50 for each additional parcel of land.

column1: LEX-FAOC158634;"Plan d’Action National de lutte contre la désertification aligné au plan cadre stratégique décennal 2008-2018.";"Pour remédier aux graves menaces de la désertification et de la dégradation de ses ressources naturelles
column2: Madagascar s’est doté d’un Plan d’Action National (PAN) de lutte contre la désertification aligné au plan cadre stratégique décennal 2008-2028. L’objectif global du PAN aligné est d’améliorer le capital productif (sol
column3: eau et ressources biologiques naturelles) comme moyen de lutte contre la désertification et la dégradation des terres. Pour atteindre cet objectif
column4: le PAN s’articule autour de deux axes principaux: le développement des connaissances et promotion de la conscientisation et de l’attitude des acteurs; et l’amélioration de la productivité et restauration des zones touchées.Dans le cadre d’une agriculture
column5: d’une sylviculture et d’une pêche plus productive et plus durable
column6: le PAN propose une gestion durable des terres et une approche intégrée dans le bassin versant de Fiherenana
column7: avec une implication multisectorielle de la gestion des unités hydrologique; la mise en œuvre d’une vision intégrée du développement durable dans la Région de Menabe face aux défis de la Biodiversité
column8: du changement climatique et de la gestion durable des terres; et le Reboisement participatif à vocation multiple dans les zones de développement des dunes du Sud-Ouest de Madagascar.Concernant la réduction de la pauvreté rurale
column9: le PAN va promouvoir la ppérennisation des sources de financement et du transfert de technologie; et la Promotion des expériences sur le «Plaidoyer
column10: la sensibilisation et l’éducation».S’agissant de l’amélioration de la résilience des moyens de subsistance face aux menaces et crises ayant des répercussions sur l’agriculture
column11: le PAN prévoit améliorer la résilience climatique du secteur Agriculture dans la région Sud-Ouest de Madagascar; mettre en place un système de gestion de connaissances en matière de lutte contre la désertification et de gestion durable des terres; mettre en place un système de gestion de connaissances en matière de lutte contre la désertification et de gestion durable des terres; renforcer les capacités d’adaptation des communautés rurales des Régions Analamanga
column12: Atsinanana
column13: Androy
column14: Anosy et Atsimo Andrefana et renforcer les capacités des parties prenantes dans le processus de lutte contre la désertification et la dégradation des terres.Dans le cadre de la gouvernance
column15: le Plan d’Action National de lutte contre la désertification aligné au plan cadre stratégique prévoit la gestion participative et durable des terres sur les prairies du plateau occidental de Madagascar. Les parties prenantes impliquées dans la mise en œuvre du PAN sont
column16: entre autres
column17: les structures les Instituts de recherche; les Populations et communautés locales; les Organisations de la Société Civiles et les Organisations Non Gouvernementales; le Secteurs privé; et les Partenaires de développement. Par ailleurs
column18: il prévoit des mécanismes et les moyens de mise en œuvre ainsi que le système de suivi évaluation des actions envisagées.

column1: LEX-FAOC153682;"Plan Nacional de Igualdad y Equidad de Género 2007-2017 (PLANEG II).";"El presente documento contiene el Plan Nacional de Igualdad y Equidad de Género 2007-2017 (PLANEG II)
column2: un plan marco que guía el accionar del país en la construcción de una sociedad que reserve un trato igualitario a la mujer salvaguardando sus derechos en función de sus necesidades particulares y universales. El plan tiene alcance nacional y adopta una perspectiva de mediano plazo
column3: relativo al período 2007-2017. La cuestión de la igualdad de género es abordada desde el enfoque de los derechos humanos. El documento está organizado en torno a siete grandes temas nacionales prioritarios a través de los cuales deberán abordarse los principales problemas que enfrentan las mujeres en la sociedad dominicana. Los temas son los siguientes: 1) promover una cultura de igualdad y equidad de género; 2) garantizar todos los derechos de las mujeres y el pleno ejercicio de su ciudadanía; 3) fortalecer el empoderamiento económico e impulsar la superación de la pobreza de las mujeres; 4) promover el liderazgo
column4: la participación y representación política y social de las mujeres en favor de la igualdad de género; 5) favorecer el acceso y control de las mujeres a bienes y servicios de calidad; 6) erradicar cualquier forma de violencia contra las mujeres en todo su ciclo de vida; 7) promover la plena participación de las mujeres en la sociedad de la información y el conocimiento.En el marco del tema nacional nº 3 (fortalecer el empoderamiento económico e impulsar la superación de la pobreza de las mujeres) se contempla como objetivo específico eliminar el hambre
column5: a través de programas de alimentación beneficiando a mujeres pobres o jefas de hogar.El plan brinda especial atención a la situación de la mujer rural y
column6: en el contexto del empoderamiento de la mujer
column7: se prevén mecanismos de asignación de propiedad rural a las mujeres.Con el objeto de propiciar sistemas agrícolas y alimentarios inclusivos que respeten el rol de la mujer
column8: se contemplan líneas de acción orientadas a desarrollar programas de capacitación laboral para mujeres que buscan primer empleo en zonas rurales. Otro objetivo en este sentido es la integración de las mujeres en el manejo y conservación de los recursos naturales y protección del medio ambiente. Se plantea que las iniciativas de políticas públicas se basen en estudios sobre el impacto de estas variables en la vida de las mujeres y que éstas participen activamente en todos los procesos decisorios relacionados con los recursos naturales y el medio ambiente. En el marco del tema nacional nº 3 se prevé superar la brecha de género en la propiedad de la tierra.A nivel de gobernanza
column9: el PLANEG II contempla mecanismos institucionales de coordinación y articulación para la implementación del plan (apartado II.1.3). Asimismo se fortalece el rol normativo del Ministerio de la Mujer. Este enfoque va de la mano con la necesidad de que el Ministerio de la Mujer ponga en marcha un sistema de seguimiento y evaluación de la ejecución del PLANEG II
column10: en coordinación con los organismos responsables de su coejecución.

column1: LEX-FAOC132859;"Décret n° 2013-2896 du 10 juillet 2013
column2: portant modification du décret n° 2001-2795 du 6 décembre 2001
column3: portant création d'une unité de gestion par objectifs pour la réalisation du projet de développement agricole intégré du bassin minier du gouvernorat de Gafsa et fixant son organisation et les modalités de son fonctionnement.";"Le présent décret modifie le décret n° 2001-2795 du 6 décembre 2001
column4: portant création d'une unité de gestion par objectifs pour la réalisation du projet de développement agricole intégré du bassin minier du gouvernorat de Gafsa et régit son organisation et les modalités de son fonctionnement.Il proroge les délais du projet de développement agricole intégré du bassin minier du gouvernorat de Gafsa de deux ans à compter de la date d'achèvement de la période fixée par l'article 3 du décret n° 2001-2795 du 6 décembre 2001
column5: tel que modifié par le décret n° 2009-9 du 5 janvier 2009.Durant cette période
column6: seront réalisées les activités suivantes: la création de deux forages de reconnaissance
column7: l'équipement et l'électrification des puits de surfaces
column8: la réalisation de divers travaux de conservation des eaux et du sol.

column1: LEX-FAOC105020;"Agricultural Small Holdings Tenure Act (Cap. 59:53).";"This Act provides protection for and regulates tenancy for agricultural purposes of land of not less than one acre nor more than fifty acres whether with or without buildings. The Act applies also to some other agricultural land tenancy. The Act prescribes statutory terms of tenancy according to the cultivation purposes of the land and sets out statutory conditions for a tenancy contract. The Act also defines rights and duties of landlords and tenants
column2: grants powers to the President to establish Agricultural Tribunals and provides with respect to proceedings to be held at such Tribunals.

column1: LEX-FAOC077996;"Radioactive Contaminated Land (Modification of Enactments) (England) (Amendment) Regulations 2007 (S.I. No. 3245 of 2007).";"These Regulations amend: (a) the Radioactive Contaminated Land (Modification of Enactments) (England) Regulations 2006 so as to apply the modifications those Regulations make to Part 2A of the Environmental Protection Act 1990 to all radioactivity; and (b) the Contaminated Land (England) Regulations 2006 to provide for a new ground of appeal against a remediation notice. Part 2A of the Environmental Protection Act 1990 sets out a regime for the identification and remediation of contaminated land. These Regulations also implement obligations arising under Articles 48 and 53 of Council Directive 1996/29/Euratom laying down basic safety standards for the protection of the health of workers and the general public against the dangers arising from ionizing radiation.

Implements: Council Directive 96/29/Euratom laying down basic safety standards for the protection of the health of workers and the general public against the dangers arising from ionizing radiation. (1996-05-13)

column1: LEX-FAOC156873;"Ley Nº 9/2001 - Ley del Suelo de la Comunidad de Madrid.";"La presente Ley del Suelo de la Comunidad de Madrid
column2: tiene por objeto la ordenación urbanística del suelo en la Comunidad de Madrid. La ordenación urbanística regula la utilización del suelo; los procesos de transformación de éste mediante la urbanización
column3: la edificación y la construcción en general o cualquiera de las otras formas previstas en la presente Ley; y el uso
column4: la explotación
column5: la conservación y la rehabilitación de las obras
column7: las construcciones y las instalaciones. La función social de la propiedad delimita el contenido de las facultades urbanísticas susceptibles de adquisición y condiciona su ejercicio. Los derechos y los deberes de la propiedad del suelo resultan de su clasificación y
column8: en su caso
column9: calificación urbanística. La utilización del suelo
column10: y en especial su urbanización y edificación
column11: deberá producirse en la forma y con las limitaciones que la legislación de ordenación territorial y urbanística establezcan
column12: de conformidad con la clasificación urbanística de los prediosEl planeamiento general clasifica el suelo del término municipal en todas o algunas de las siguientes clases: 1) suelo urbano; 2) suelo urbanizable; y 3) suelo no urbanizable de protección.

column1: LEX-FAOC075849;"Town and Country Planning (General Development Procedure) (England) (Amendment) Order 2006 (S.I. 1062 of 2006).";"These Regulations amend the Town and Country Planning (General Development Procedure) Order 1995. They specify what needs to be included in applications for outline planning permission in relation to “reserved matters” (as redefined by these Regulations and including landscaping and access).The Regulations also amend the Order in consequence of provisions in the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 and so as to provide anew for the preparation and revocation of local development orders by local planning authorities. These Regulations also provide for registers of local development orders.

Amends: Town and Country Planning (General Development Procedure) Order 1995 (S.I. 419 of 1995). column1: LEX-FAOC025499;"Land Code
column2: Law No. 1103-1 of 1991.";"The purpose of Land Legislation of the RSFSR is to regulate land relations with the object of providing for the rational use and protection of land
column3: setting up conditions for equal development of various forms of economic activity on land
column4: re-production of soil fertility
column5: conservation and improvement of environment and safeguarding of the rights of landownership of citizens
column7: institutions and organizations. The document consists of XV Sections that contain 127 Articles. Sections I
column8: III
column9: IV are sub-divided into Chapters. Section I contains 8 Chapters. Chapter 1 lays down the general provisions. Chapter 4 regards expropriation
column10: allotment and concession into private property and in lease of the plots of land. Chapter 5 establishes the modalities of expropriation and allotment of the plots of land. Chapter 6 deals with cessation of the rights on land. Chapter 7 deals with the use of land for prospecting purpose. Chapter 8 concerns land tax
column11: rent and royalties for the purchase of land. Section II determines the rights and the duties of the landowners
column12: landlords
column13: leaseholders and land tenants
column14: protection and safeguard of their rights. Section III regards agricultural land. Chapter 9 lays down the general provisions. Chapter 10 regards peasants' (farmers') land. Chapter 11 regards plots of land destined for subsidiary smallholding
column15: gardening
column16: stockbreeding
column17: truck farming
column18: haymaking and grazing. Chapter 12 regards collective farms' land
column19: agricultural cooperatives' land
column20: state farms' land and land belonging to other agricultural enterprises
column21: institutions and organizations. Section IV regards populated areas land. Chapter 13 regards urban land
column22: settlement land and rural settlements' land. Section V regards land belonging to industrial enterprises
column23: transport
column24: communications
column25: broadcasting
column26: television
column27: information and space installations
column28: defence installations and land destined for other purposes. Section VI concerns land destined for environmental protection
column31: historical and cultural heritage. Section VII regards forestland
column32: water land and stock of land. Section VIII establishes the modalities of indemnification of the landowners
column34: leaseholders and land tenants for agricultural agro-forestry losses. Section IX deals with land protection. Section X regards control over the use and protection of land. Section XI regards state land cadastre. Section XII regards land survey. Section XIII regards dispute settlement. Section XIV establishes liability for the infringement of land legislation. Section XV regards international agreements.

column1: LEX-FAOC149624;"Integrated Food Security Strategy for South Africa.";"The Integrated Food Security Strategy for South Africa is a sectoral national strategy of South Africa in force for the period of 2002-2015. Its main goal is to eradicate hunger
column2: malnutrition and food insecurity over 2015. The strategic objectives are: increasing household food production and trading; improving income generation and job creation opportunities; improving nutrition and food safety; increasing safety nets and food emergency management systems; improving analysis and information management system; providing capacity building; and holding stakeholder dialogue.The Strategy treats the issue of nutrition and food safety providing for the following measures: (1) enhancing public education; (2) improving monitoring methods and support stronger multi-sectoral partnerships; (3) supporting targeted interventions (e.g. micronutrients
column3: vitamin supplements) for the chronically vulnerable groups; (4) strengthening household food security and nutrition training at both pre- and in-service training level and equip the trainees with skills to integrate it and nutrition concerns in development programmes.Additionally
column4: it also discusses the issue of safety nets and food emergency management systems providing for the following actions: (1) strengthening public goods
column5: such as infrastructure
column7: research and extension and technology development to the benefit of farmers and rural dwellers; (2) creating effective cost-recovery programmes when services are provided by the private sector; (3) strengthening the coordination and management of emergency relief operations at national and provincial level; (4) compiling baseline information to assess the food insecurity and vulnerability situation of the country; 5) ensuring periodic programme evaluations and feasibility studies; (6) including mapping techniques and Geographic Information System to analyse complex food insecurity and vulnerability information in ways that greatly facilitate understanding and decision-making; (7) ensuring effective product dissemination; and (8) establishing a technical team for food security data and establish a National Food Security Steering Committee to monitor and evaluate progress of the Strategy.Additionally
column8: the Strategy also targets to improve household food production
column9: trade and distribution laying down the following objectives: (1) increasing access to productive resources such as land
column10: technology
column11: credit and training; (2) promote small-scale irrigation and other rainwater harnessing technologies; (3) investing in productivity-enhancing
column12: environmentally sustainable technologies for the agriculture and agro-processing sector
column13: targeting small-scale producers; (4) linking land/water and tenure reform to other farmer support services
column14: including access to financial services and markets; (5) improving access to credit by the poor
column15: including women; (6) promoting the use of idle agricultural land through agrarian reforms; (7) improving access to food production and food processing technologies; (8) improving extension services where extension workers respond to the needs of small-scale farmers who often practice mixed farming and undertake a variety of enterprises; (9) supporting extension agents to disseminate information through the media; (10) improving trade by monitoring the impact of liberalised trade regimes on the incomes and welfare of food insecure groups; (11) enhancing the ownership and exchange entitlement of the poor in the trade of agriculture and food sectors; (12) protecting the agriculture and food sector against unfair trade practices; (13) removing import duties through a support scheme that ensures that government expenditure on social development and empowerment of the vulnerable groups does not diminish and conforms to the WTO regulations; (14) improving household food security by commercialising agriculture to increase income and employment generation among food insecure households; (15) improving rural infrastructure by a proportional cost-sharing approach
column16: which involves the Government
column17: private sector and local communities; and (16) investing in food distribution facilities to move food to deficit areas.Also
column18: income and job opportunities are planned to be increased through: (1) supporting diversified job creation through local economic development
column19: including the growth of small and medium scale enterprises; (2) supporting labour-intensive public work programmes in rural
column20: agricultural areas to simultaneously address chronic problems of food insecurity
column21: unemployment and poor infrastructure
column22: and create productive assets; (3) strengthening off-farm income generation; (4) strengthening access to rural credit facilities; (5) strengthening market systems
column23: i.e. information
column24: infrastructure
column25: etc.; and (6) supporting skills training to create viable income generation activities.In terms of the implementation of the Strategy
column26: at the highest level of the structure is the Inter-Ministerial Committee composed of two clusters
column27: one social and one economic. The Minister of Agriculture will chair the team. The role of the team is to give a political direction by making policy decisions and report to the President and to parliament about food security targets (progress). Stakeholders from public sector
column28: private sector and civil society will constitute the National Food Security Forum.

column4: and subletting which shall enhance the hire of immovable property for use in the commercial or industrial business in the long term.A lease of a land which has an area exceeding 100 rai shall require the approval of the Director-General in accordance with the rules

column1: LEX-FAOC152488;"Agriculture Gender Strategy.";"The development of the Agriculture Gender Strategy is in line with Rwanda’s Constitution of 2003
column2: the Economic Development and Poverty Reduction Strategy (EDPRS)
column3: the National Gender Policy and MINAGRI’s Strategic Plan for the Transformation of Agriculture in Rwanda-Phase II (PSTA-II). These provide the need for equality between men and women and boys and girls in all spheres of socio-economic development. As such
column4: gender will be mainstreamed in the implementation of the PSTA II programs.The overall objectives of the gender strategy is to contribute to poverty reduction and sustainable development through institutionalisation of gender responsive programming (planning and budgeting)
column5: implementation
column6: monitoring and reporting systems and improve gender equality in agriculture sector.The gender strategy will enable the MINAGRI and its partners effectively respond to the practical needs and strategic gender interests of both men and women farmers.The strategic objectives are: (i) to institutionalise gender equality in the agriculture sector
column7: (ii) to develop capacities in the agriculture sector to enable gender sensitive programming
column8: (iii) to enhance the gender responsiveness in delivery of agricultural services
column9: (iv) to promote equal participation in decision making processes.In order to make agriculture
column10: forestry and fisheries more productive and sustainable
column11: the government plans to enhance the gender responsiveness in delivery of agricultural services will focus on a number of activities to promote gender equality
column12: including: land use consolidation
column13: agricultural mechanisation
column14: fertilisers and seeds
column15: one cow per poor family.Regarding the reduction of the rural poverty
column16: the government plans to implement the following strategies: (i) train rural women and men in soft skills that include leadership
column17: interpersonal communication
column18: conflict resolution
column19: (ii) development and establishment of mechanisms for inclusion of gender related issues in SWAP
column20: (iii) to develop and coordinate partnerships and collaborative mechanisms amongst government institutions
column21: CSOs
column22: private sector and development partners and integrate appropriate actions to respond to practical and strategic gender needs in the agriculture sector
column23: (iv) supporting farmers
column24: especially women
column25: in project formulation and other soft skills (entrepreneurship
column26: leadership
column27: teamwork
column28: conflict management)
column29: (v) communication and awareness on existing facilities (RIF2
column30: agriculture and women guarantee fund) so that both women and men farmers and entrepreneurs have enough knowledge on how to access the funds
column31: (vi) develop operational guidelines and procedures to facilitate equal access by women and men to opportunities and services that are channeled through farmer organisations and cooperatives
column32: including women representation (at least 30%) in those structures and their active participation in decision making processes.In the context of governance
column33: the implementation will be facilitated by a gender steering committee (GSC) primarily comprising of not more than 8 members
column34: one from each of the following ministries MINAGRI
column39: Gender Monitoring Office and the Gender Specialist employed by MINAGRI. It is envisaged that the role of the GSC will be to provide overall strategic direction in implementing the plan and advice on gender mainstreaming issues. The committee will also be responsible for
column40: publicity and marketing the strategy. MINAGRI with the coordination of the Gender Specialist will collaborate with relevant government institutions and agencies such as stated above as well as the private sector
column41: development partners and NGOs for the implementation of the strategy.

column3: water and soil
column4: as well as the avoidance of noise; the conservation or reinstatement of a healthy nature
column5: the protection of the indigenous fauna and flora and their natural living spaces
column7: finally
column8: in particular that of housing and recreational areas. The text consists of 117 articles divided into 5 Parts as follows: National land use planning (I); Local land use planning (II); Land consolidation (III); Land Use Planning Fund (IV); Final and transitional provisions (V)

column1: LEX-FAOC047357;"Agricultural Holdings (Scotland) Act 2003 (2003 asp 11).";"The Act consists of 95 sections divided into 8 Parts. In Chpater I of Part I the various types of agricultural tenancy are defined. Chapter 2 contains general provision as to new types of tenancy. Part 2 provides for the tenant's right to buy land. Part III concerns diversification of use of land under agricultural tenancy. A tenant under a tenancy mentioned in section 39(1) who intends to use the land for a non-agricultural purpose must send a notice to the landlord. The landlord may object to the notice of diversification under certain circumstances (sect. 40). Where the Land Court determines that an objection by the landlord to a notice of diversification is unreasonable the objection shall be of no effect and the land may be used as planned. The tenant under specified tenancies has
column2: for so long as the tenancy continues to have effect
column3: the right to cut timber from any trees planted on the land by the tenant on or after the coming into force of this section; and any such timber belongs to the tenant (sect. 42). Part 7 concerns jurisdiction of the Land Court.

column1: LEX-FAOC035060;"Nitrate Vulnerable Zones (Additional Designations) (England) (No. 2) Regulations 2002 (S.I. No. 2614 of 2002).";"These Regulations designate additional nitrate vulnerable zones and make other provision for the purpose of implementing in England Council Directive 91/676/EEC concerning the protection of waters against pollution caused by nitrates from agricultural sources. Regulation 3 designates the additional nitrate vulnerable zones. Regulation 4 provides a procedure for reviewing designations. Regulation 5 provides for appeals to be made from proposed decisions on a review. Regulation 6 makes provision for withdrawing an appeal. Regulation 7 deals with the costs of the parties to an appeal. Regulation 8 provides for the Secretary of State to be bound by any decision made on a review. Amendments to the Protection of Water Against Agricultural Nitrate Pollution (England and Wales) Regulations 1996 concern periodic review of designations
column2: monitoring and implementation
column3: periodic review and monitoring of action programmes. The Farm Waste Grant (Nitrate Vulnerable Zones) (England) (No. 2) Scheme 2000 is amended so that grants are available in relation to farms in the additional nitrate vulnerable zones. Regulation 11 applies the Action Programme for Nitrate Vulnerable Zones (England and Wales) Regulations 1998 to the additional nitrate vulnerable zones. The action programme in those Regulations defines the measures which must be taken on farms and livestock units to limit the application of nitrates to land.

column1: Implements: Council Directive 91/676/EEC concerning the protection of waters against pollution caused by nitrates from agricultural sources. (1991-12-12)

column1: LEX-FAOC157279;"Regional Decree No. 291 “On the modalities of performance of municipal land control”.";"This Regional Decree establishes the modalities of performance of municipal land control by local government. Municipal land control shall be conducted in the form of ordinary and extraordinary inspections of legal persona and individual entrepreneurs. The subject of inspection shall be checking data and information contained in the documentation related to land tenure. The scope of inspection shall be to control compliance by land tenant with compulsory legislative requirements related to land tenure with a view of prevention and suppression of unauthorized transactions with land. Municipal land control shall be performed in accordance with the annual plans. The outcome of municipal land control shall be legalized in the form of inspection certificate.
