column1: LEX-FAOC024810;"Ministerial Decree No. 299 regarding the validation of the Regulation on the modalities of valuation of agricultural and forestry damages caused to owners or land tenants by expropriation of agricultural land and forests for the purposes not connected with agriculture and forestry.";"The Government decrees to validate the Regulation in accordance with Annex 1
column2: to validate compensation norms for agricultural and forestry damages in accordance with Annexes 23 and to establish compensation factor for forestry damages and for land deterioration in accordance with Annex 4. Compensation royalties for agricultural and forestry damages are refunded to the republican budget. Annex 1 contains the Regulation that comprises 3 Sections subdivided in 29 paragraphs. Section 1 lays down the general provisions. Section 2 deals with the compensation for agricultural and forestry damages. Section 3 regards indemnification. Annex 2 regards compensation norms for agricultural damages that are calculated for hectare. Annex 3 regards compensation norms for forestry damages that are calculated for hectare in accordance with the classification of the types of forests. Annex 4 regards compensation factor for forestry damages and for land deterioration in accordance with the classification of the types of forests.

column1: LEX-FAOC105247;"National Trust of Trinidad and Tobago Act (Cap. 40:53).";"This Act establishes the National Trust of Trinidad and Tobago as a body corporate and provides that it shall be governed by rules set out in the Schedule. The Trust is establish for purposes of carrying out functions pursuant to the present Act
column2: including listing of property of interest
column3: preserving lands
column4: plants and animal life
column5: encourage research of wild fauna and flora
column6: etc. Powers of the trust are outlined in section 6. Sections 8 and 9 provide for listing of places of particular interest. The Trust shall be administered by a Council. Section 27 prohibits damaging of listed property. The Second Schedule contains the National Trust Regulations. They deal with grading of listed properties and registration of listed lands.

column1: LEX-FAOC050321;"Planning and Zoning Act 1987.";"The Act provides for the planning of land and water use and the creation of zones for specific purposes. Section 3 sets out the tasks of the Chief Planner
column2: who shall be an adviser in planning to central and local authorities. Every local government council shall establish a planning commission in accordance with section 4. The mayor shall be chairman of the commission. A commission shall examine and decide on matters in the framework of this Act. All local government offices have a planning office. Sections 10 and following provide for zoning
column3: i.e. zoning may take place for purposes set out in article 121. Zoning may include watershed zones providing exclusively for the catchment
column4: collection
column5: storage and distribution of water. The National government may acquire land for the local government for purposes of this Act and use of such land shall be deemed to be public use under the Land Acquisition Act 1986.

column1: LEX-FAOC127463;"Constitution of the United Republic of Tanzania
column2: 1977.";"The Constitution of the Republic of Tanzania was ratified in 1977. Since 1977
column3: several amendments have been applied to the original Constitution. Many of these are related to the relationship between the united government and the Zanzibar government. This Constitution shall apply to Mainland Tanzania as well as Tanzania Zanzibar. The Constitution consists of 152 articles divided in 10 Chapters: The United Republic
column4: political parties
column5: the people and the policy of socialism and self reliance (1); The Executive of The United Republic (2); The Legislature of The United Republic (3); The Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar
column6: The Zanzibar Revolutionary Council and the House of Representatives of Zanzibar (4); Dispensation of Justice in The United Republic (5); The Commission For Human Rights and Good Governance and the Public Leaders’ Ethics Secretariat (6); Provisions Regarding the Finances of The United Republic (7); Public Authorities (8);Armed Forces (9); Miscellaneous Provisions. It is completed by a Preamble and two Schedules. The First Schedule specifies
column7: for purposes of article 4
column8: matters of the Union. The Second Schedule lists Laws the amendment of which requires to be supported by at least two-thirds of all Members of Parliament.Tanzania is one State and is a sovereign United Republic (art. 1). The United Republic is a democratic
column9: secular and socialist state which adheres to multi-party democracy (art. 3). All state authority in the United Republic shall be exercised and controlled by two organs vested with executive powers
column10: two organs vested with judicial powers and two organs vested with legislative and supervisory powers over the conduct of public affairs. The organs vested with executive powers shall be the Government of the United Republic and the Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar; the organs vested with judicial powers shall be the Judiciary of the United Republic and the Judiciary of the Revolutionary government of Zanzibar; and the organs vested with legislative and supervisory powers over public affairs shall be the Parliament of the Untied Republic and the House of Representatives (art. 4). The President shall be the Head of State
column11: the Head of Government and the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces. Subject to the other provisions of this Constitution and of any other law
column12: the President shall have authority to constitute and to abolish any office in the service of the Government of the United Republic. There shall be established local government authorities in each region
column13: district
column14: urban area and village in the United Republic
column15: which shall be of the type and designation prescribed by law to be enacted by Parliament or by the House of Representatives (art. 145).Article 30 concerns limitations upon
column16: and enforcement and preservation of basic rights
column17: freedoms and duties. The President may proclaim a state of emergency in circumstances indicated in article 32. There shall be a Commission to be known as the Commission for Human Rights and Good Governance
column18: whose functions shall be as prescribed in article 130 of this Constitution. The Constitution also a Public Leaders’ Ethics Secretariat
column19: which shall have power to inquire into the behaviour and conduct of any public leader. In general amendments to the Constitution require the votes of two-thirds of all the members of the National Assembly. Amendments that affect the constitutional arrangements that constitute the Union with Zanzibar require a two-thirds majority of the National Assembly and the Zanzibari House of Representatives (art. 398)Taking into account the object of this Constitution the state authority and all its agencies are obliged to direct their policies and programmes towards ensuring
column20: among other things: according equal opportunities to all citizens
column21: men and women alike without regard to their colour
column22: tribe
column23: religion
column24: or station in life; directing national wealth towards the eradication of poverty
column25: ignorance and disease. All persons are equal before the law and are entitled
column26: without any discrimination
column27: to protection and equality before the law (art. 13). Every person is entitled to own property
column28: and has a right to the protection of his property held in accordance with the law. It shall be unlawful for any person to be deprived of his property for the purposes of nationalization or any other purposes without the authority of law which makes provision for fair and adequate compensation (art. 24). Every person has the duty to protect the natural resources of the United Republic
column29: the property of the state authority
column30: all property collectively owned by the people
column31: and also to respect another person’s property.

column1: LEX-FAOC156906;"Regional Law No. 240-OD “On public control”.";"This Regional Law establishes the modalities of organization and performance of public control as a form of public participation. It shall not be applicable to elections and referendum. Regional executive bodies shall have the following plenary powers: (a) formation of advisory councils at the regional executive bodies; (b) examination of final documents drafted by public control bodies; and (c) consideration of proposals
column2: recommendations and conclusions contained in the final documents. Public control shall be performed by the Public (Civic) Chambers
column3: advisory councils at the regional executive bodies and local government
column4: public inspections and public control groups. Public control can initiate public hearings
column5: obtain results of inspections performed by regional and municipal executive bodies and participate at joint supervisory (control) arrangements.

column1: LEX-FAOC008523;"Règlement grand-ducal concernant l'utilisation de fertilisants organiques dans l'agriculture.";"Ce règlement vise à réduire la pollution des eaux provoquéé ou induite par les nitrates à partir de fertilisants organiques et prévenir toute nouvelle pollution de ce type; réduire ou prévenir les nuisances causées par l'épandage de fertilisants organiques. L'article 2 contient la définition de certains termes employés comme
column2: parmi d'autres
column3: ""composé azoté""
column4: ""animaux""
column5: ""engrais chimique""
column6: ""effluent d'élevage"". L'article 3 indique les autorités competentes. Les ministres de l'agriculture et de l'environnement font établir un code de bonnes pratiques agricoles que sera fourni à tous les exploitants agricoles. L'article 5 contient les interdictions et restrictions spéciales applicables dans les zones de protection des eaux potables. En outre
column7: ce règlement modifie l'article 4 du règlement du 14 avril 1990 relatif aux boues d'épuration. Le règlement comprend 11 articles.

column1: Mis en oeuvre par: Règlement ministériel autorisant
column2: à titre exceptionnel
column3: l'épandage de lisier et de purin sur des sols gelés ou enneigés. (1998-12-07)

column1: LEX-FAOC017630;"Transformation of Certain Rural Areas Act.";"At the commencement of this Act
column2: all trust land situated in a township must vest in the municipality of the area where such land is situated
column3: subject to the continued existence of any registered or registrable rights of a person in or over a piece of land in the township. Trust land in the remainder or land in the remainder which vests in a municipality in terms of a law listed in the Schedule
column4: may be transferred to an entity at any time prior to the expiry of the transitional period. No transfer of such land must take place unless the Minister is satisfied that
column5: in the event of a transfer to: (a) municipality
column6: the legislation applicable to such a municipality; or (b) a communal property association or other body approved by the Minister
column7: the rules of such association or body
column8: make suitable provision for a balance of security of tenure rights and protection of rights of use of: (i) the residents mutually; (ii) individual members of such a communal property association or other body; (iii) present and future users or occupiers of land
column9: and the public interest of access to land on the remainder and the continued existence or termination of any existing right or interest of a person in such land.

column1: LEX-FAOC139984;"Order No. 94 on subsidies for conversion to organic farming.";"The Danish AgriFish Agency may grant subsidies to owners and tenants of farms in order to convert agricultural land to organic farming. The Order’s provisions are designed to meet a market demand for organic production through conversion to organic agricultural production by up to 18 000 ha/year (including 2013). The areas subject to such conversion include grasslands
column2: uncultivated areas
column3: areas (forests) growing decorative trees
column4: however excludes afforested areas
column5: areas covered by subsidy provisions for forestry
column6: areas within commitment on forest protection (except non-vegetated forest reserve areas)
column7: areas not in agreement for allocation of funds pursuant wetland restoration provisions. Request for subsidy shall be ensured by electronic application to the Agency’s website and criteria for eligibility consists of granting support to authorized organic agricultural production farms. Subsidy commitment period lasts five years – from 1 September in the year of application to 31 August.The Order consists of 12 Chapters: Scheme content and purpose (1); Definitions (2); Administration (3); Commitment period and conditions thereof (4); Amending the commitment and its onset (5); Calculation of subsidy (6); Payment of subsidies (7); Duty to notify (8); Expiry of commitment and recovery of subsidy (9); Force majeure (10); Appeals (11); Entry into force (12).

column1: LEX-FAOC039218;"Mining Act.";"The Act consists of 86 sections divided into 9 Parts: Administration (I); Concessions and leases (II); Licenses (III); Mining licenses on State Lands (IV); Mining partnerships (V); Prevention of theft of raw gold or silver
column2: or of valuable minerals or precious stones (VI); Offences (VII); Procedure (VIII); Miscellaneous (IX).The Commissioner of Geological Surveys and Mines shall have charge of metals and minerals and act as guardian of such resources. The Minister may declare Mining Districts under section 4 and for each Mining District a Mines Officer shall be appointed pursuant to section 5. The Mines Officers shall act under directions of the Commissioner. Powers of these officers and the Commissioner are set out in section 10. The Minister may grant mining concessions in accordance with sections 11 and 12 and a permission to explore under section 13. Land rights may be granted in respect of unoccupied land under section 16. Timber on land covered by concession or lease may be cut but if the timber is removed a royalty must be paid (sects. 17 and 18). Land under concession or lease may be required for public purposes. A mining license may be issued by the Commissioner
column3: with approval of the President
column4: under section 28. Section 33 and following concern mining licenses on private lands. Regulation making powers of the Minister are set out in section 79. They include the regulation of water use and water rights and use of surface of land and cutting of timber.

column1: LEX-FAOC086699;"Order No. 10/2008/L-CTN on the promulgation of the Law on Compulsory Purchase and Requisition of Property.";"This Law provides for the compulsory purchase and requisition of property which may be conducted only in case of real necessity for defence or security reasons and national interests.The Law provides for: property subject to compulsory purchase or subject to requisition; rights and responsibilities of state agencies in compulsory purchase and requisition of property; rights and obligations of persons whose property is compulsorily purchased or requisitioned; contents of decisions on compulsory purchase or requisition of property; etc.Persons whose property is compulsorily purchased will be paid sums of money for the purchase of their property while persons whose property is requisitioned and who suffer property damage caused by the requisition will be paid compensations calculated according to market prices.
Amends: Order No. 12/2007/L-CTN on the promulgation of the Law on Prevention and Control of Infectious Diseases. (2007-12-05)
Amends: Order No. 24/2006/L-CTN on the Promulgation of the Law on Dikes. (2006-12-12)

Amends: Order No. 23/2003/L-CTN on the promulgation of Land Law No.13/2003/QH11. column1: LEX-FAOC085010;"Loi nº 2008-005 portant loi-cadre sur l'environnement.";"La présente loi fixe le cadre juridique général de gestion de l’environnement au Togo. Elle vise à : -préserver et gérer durablement l’environnement; - garantir
column2: à tous les citoyens
column3: un cadre de vie écologiquement sain et équilibré; - créer les conditions d’une gestion rationnelle et durable des ressources naturelles pour les générations présentes et futures; - établir les principes fondamentaux destinés à gérer
column4: à préserver l’environnement contre toutes les formes de dégradation afin de valoriser les ressources naturelles
column5: de lutter contre toutes sortes de pollutions et nuisances; - améliorer durablement les conditions de vie des populations dans le respect de l’équilibre avec le milieu ambiant.Le gouvernement définit
column6: avec la participation des parties prenantes au développement
column7: la politique nationale de l’environnement et veille à sa mise en oeuvre. La politique nationale de l’environnement prévoit les mesures nécessaires et les dispositifs adéquats susceptibles de surveiller la qualité de l’environnement
column8: prévenir et lutter contre les pollutions
column9: les nuisances
column10: les catastrophes naturelles et technologiques et préserver les ressources naturelles. La mise en oeuvre de la politique nationale de l’environnement est assurée par le ministère chargé de l’environnement en relation avec les autres ministères et institutions concernés. Il est créé et placé sous la tutelle du ministre chargé de l’environnement
column11: des organismes de consultation et des établissements publics
column12: à savoir : la Commission nationale du développement durable
column13: l’Agence Nationale de Gestion de l’Environnement
column14: le Fonds National de l’Environnement. L’Etat
column15: les collectivités territoriales et les institutions concernées par la gestion de l’environnement font participer les populations et associations à l’élaboration de toutes politiques
column16: tous plans
column17: toutes stratégies
column18: tous programmes et projets relatifs à la gestion de l’environnement. Ils assurent la promotion des pratiques traditionnelles éprouvées de gestion durable des ressources naturelles au niveau des communautés de base. Les différents acteurs du développement sont tenus
column19: dans le cadre de leurs actions
column20: de sensibiliser
column21: d’éduquer et d’informer les populations aux problèmes de l’environnement en vue de leur participation à sa gestion.Le gouvernement
column22: en rapport avec les institutions et les partenaires concernés
column23: élabore et met en oeuvre un plan national d’action pour l’environnement
column24: qui est révisé tous les 5 ans. Autres outils de gestion sont les études d’impact sur l’environnement et l’audit environnemental
column25: le système d’information et de suivi environnemental et la fixation de normes de qualité. les mesures de protection concernent plus spécifiquement le sol
column26: le sous-sol et les richesses qu’ils contiennent
column27: la faune et de la flore
column28: les eaux continentales
column31: l’atmosphère
column34: le contrôle et à la surveillance des substances chimiques nocives ou dangereuses
column35: la lutte contre la désertification et les changements climatiques et la mise en place des règles préventives
column36: des systèmes d’alerte et de réduction des risques.

column1: LEX-FAOC160154;"Land Surveyors Act (C.C.S.M. c. L60).";"The present Act lays down provisions relating to the practice of land surveying for the protection of the public and administration of the profession. Section 6 establishes that the Association of Manitoba Land Surveyors is continued as a body corporate. The purpose of the association is to: a) uphold and protect the public interest in the delivery of land surveying services by ensuring the competence
column2: integrity and independence of its members; and b) act in the public interest in matters affecting the protection
column3: viability and security of the land tenure system in Manitoba. The text consists of 89 sections divided into 14 Parts as follows: Interpretation (1); Practice of land surveying (2); Association of Manitoba Land Surveyors (3); By-laws (4); Registration and licensing (5); Professional corporations (6); Complaints (7); Rights and powers of land surveyors (8); Prohibitions (9); Compliance (10); General provisions (11); Joint Board on Inter-professional Issues (12); Related and consequential amendments (13); Transitional
column4: repeal and coming into force (14).

column1: LEX-FAOC082292;"Land and Environment Court Rules 2007.";"These Rules prescribe the general practice applicable to all proceedings to be commenced in the Land and Environment Court. They are divided into 6 Parts. Part 2 concerns the administration. In particular
column2: it deals with the following matters: seal of the court
column3: sittings of the court
column4: vacation
column5: registry
column6: judges and assessors. Part 3 applies to proceedings in Class 1
column7: 2 or 3 of the Court's jurisdiction. It regulates: The originating process
column8: Where reference to other body required; Parties to appeals under the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979; Public authority to make documents available; Costs in certain proceedings; Neutral evaluation
column9: a process of evaluation of a dispute in which the evaluator seeks to identify and reduce the issues of fact and law in dispute
column10: including by assessing the relative strengths and weaknesses of each party's case and offering an opinion as to the likely outcome of the proceedings; and Court functions not exercisable by Commissioners. Part 4 applies to proceedings in Class 4 of the Court's jurisdiction and regulates: Proceedings brought in the public interest; Proceedings for the review of public authority's decision; and Neutral evaluation. Part5 applies to proceedings in Class 5
column11: 6 or 7 of the Court's jurisdiction.

column1: LEX-FAOC060599;"Deeds Registries Act [Chapter 20:05].";"This Act principally makes provision for the making and registration of deeds regarding land and other real rights
column2: for rights in land such as lease and servitude and for the transfer of land.The Act consists of 88 section divided into 7 Parts: Preliminary (I); Administration (II); Registration (III); Registration of land (IV); Bonds (V); Rights in immovable property (VI); General (VII).There shall exist registries of deeds as set out in section 3. The Minister shall appoint a Chief Registrar of Deeds and may appoint other registrars of deeds pursuant to section 4. Duties of registrars are set out in section 5. Section 14 states that
column3: subject to this Act or any other law the ownership of land may be conveyed from one person to another only by means of a deed of transfer executed or attested by a registrar. Section 16 of Part IV concerns the transfer of State land. Subject to the provisions of section 18
column4: the appropriate Minister may direct a registrar to cancel the title deed of any land owned by the State under title deed or land in respect of which the State has the right to claim transfer. Other provisions of Part IV concern the transfer of other land and the certificate of title.

column1: LEX-FAOC157054;"Regional Decree No. 679 “On the modalities of performance of municipal land control”.";"This Regional Decree establishes the modalities of performance of municipal land control by local government. Municipal land control shall be conducted in the form of ordinary and extraordinary inspections of legal persona and individual entrepreneurs. The subject of inspection shall be checking data and information contained in the documentation related to land tenure. The scope of inspection shall be to control compliance by land tenant with compulsory legislative requirements related to land tenure with a view of prevention and suppression of unauthorized transactions with land. Municipal land control shall be performed in accordance with the annual plans. The outcome of municipal land control shall be legalized in the form of inspection certificate.

Amended by: Regional Law No. 91 amending Regional Decree No. 679 “On the modalities of performance of municipal land control”. column1: LEX-FAOC164533;"Subdivision Regulations
column2: 2014 (R.R.S. c. P-13.2 Reg. 2).";"The present Regulations are made under the Planning and Development Act 2007
column3: the Land Titles Act
column4: 2000 and the Land Surveys Act
column5: 2000. In particular
column6: the Regulations accomplish three major objectives: 1) Performance of regulatory review and update to ensure that the Regulations align with the Planning and Development Act
column7: 2007 and the Statements of Provincial Interest Regulations; 2) Adoption of a new fee schedule
column8: phased in over three years
column9: that will approach cost-recovery for reviewing subdivision applications; 3) Efficiency improvements that will improve the timely review of subdivisions. Furthermore
column10: the Regulations require new development to locate 125 meters from existing oil or gas wells and facilities in order to ensure public safety is protected. This distance may be increased or decreased by the approving authority as required after consultation occurs with the Ministry of the Economy. The text consists of 22 sections and 1 Appendix.

column1: LEX-FAOC104265;"Ministerial Decree No. 311 validating the Regulation on drawing up and issuance of land certificates.";"This Ministerial Decree establishes the modalities of drawing up and issuance of certificate attesting rights to the plots of land for natural and legal persons. In case of concession of a plot of land in ownership or use entitling documents shall be: (a) official act on the right of ownership of a plot of land; (b) official act on open-ended land tenure of a plot of land; (c) provisional land tenure certificate or lease contract; and (d) land ownership certificate. Land ownership certificate shall be issued to natural persons in the following cases: (a) to citizens who obtained land shares after enactment of Land Code; (b) to owners of land shares who of their own free will want to substitute previously issued land tenure certificate with land ownership certificate by their written application; (c) duplicates; (d) in case of land transactions to a new landowner; (d) transfer of rights as legal succession; (e) transfer of rights as inheritance.

column1: LEX-FAOC050699;"Law No. 254-Z on land surveying and cartographic activity.";"This Act consists of 21 Articles. It establishes the legal basis for activity in the sphere of land survey and cartography. Objects of land surveying and cartographic activity are the national territory
column2: continents of the terrestrial globe and World Ocean
column3: including islands
column4: outer space
column5: including planets and the products of land surveying and cartographic activity. Land surveying and cartographic activity includes: (a) creation
column6: renewal and editing of state topographic maps of inhabited settlements; (b) distant zoning of the Earth; (c) creation and keeping State cartographic and land surveying fund and state geographic information systems and cadastres; (d) mapping and demarcation of administrative boundaries; (i) zoning of the bottom of water bodies and water reservoirs. Special purpose land surveying and cartographic activity includes: (a) mapping for agroforestry; (b) land survey
column7: drainage and land reclamation; (c) inventory.

column1: LEX-FAOC047772;"Nature Conservation (Scotland) Act 2004 (2004 asp 6).";"The Act sets out a series of measures which are designed to conserve biodiversity and to protect and enhance the biological and geological natural heritage of Scotland. In doing so
column2: the Act provides the principal legislative components of a new
column3: integrated
column4: system for nature conservation within Scotland. The Act also locates the conservation of biodiversity and of Scotland's natural environment within a wider British
column5: European and global context. In relation to biodiversity in particular
column6: it requires public bodies and office-holders to consider the effect of their actions at a local
column7: regional
column8: national and international level.The Act is divided in 5 parts and contributes to the new system for nature conservation by means of a combination of both new measures and amendments to existing legislation. In Part 1 it introduces a new general duty on all public bodies and office holders to further the conservation of biodiversity. In the exercise of their functions
column9: they must have regard
column10: among other things
column11: to the Convention on Biological Diversity of 1992. Part 2 makes changes to the existing arrangements for the establishment and protection of sites of special scientific interest. In doing so
column12: it replaces most of Part II of the existing Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (c.69). The Act extends in Part 3 the law in relation to the protection of birds
column13: animals and plants by making significant amendments to the current provisions of Part I of the 1981 Act and by requiring production of a new code of guidance covering whale and dolphin watching and similar activities. Part 4 requires the creation by Scottish Natural Heritage of a code of guidance setting out recommendations
column14: advice and information relating to fossils. Part 5 provides for various supplemental matters including the publication of statutory guidance about the duty to further the conservation of biodiversity and Scottish Natural Heritage's functions under Part 2 and for minor and consequential amendments and repeals to a variety of other Statutes.

Amends: Water Industry (Scotland) Act 2002. (2002-03-01)";"Hupperts

column1: LEX-FAOC164531;"Statements of Provincial Interest Regulations (R.R.S. c. P-13.2 Reg. 3).";"The present Regulations are made under the Planning and Development Act 200. In particular
column2: the purpose of the Statements of Provincial Interest is to: 1) identify provincial interests to guide provincial and municipal planning decisions in the development of safe and secure communities; 2) align provincial and municipal planning objectives to facilitate orderly development that is beneficial to communities; and 3) guide the development of economically
column3: environmentally
column4: socially and culturally sustainable communities.The following principles provide a context for decision-making
column5: are relevant to the design of official community plans
column7: zoning bylaws and subdivision bylaws and are an integral part of interpreting and applying the Statements of Provincial Interest: 1) Comprehensive and sustainable planning requires land use plans and development decisions to consider economic
column8: social
column9: cultural and environmental needs of communities and regions for present and future generations; 2) Responsive and sensitive planning recognizes the importance of stakeholders and the contribution that they bring throughout the planning process; 3) Respectful and balanced planning provides an atmosphere of mutual respect and encourages discussion that balances the interests of all stakeholders in the management of common provincial resources and the development of economic
column10: social
column11: cultural and environmental opportunities; 4) Efficient and effective planning considers the orderly and beneficial development of land uses
column12: infrastructure and community services to ensure public safety
column13: to meet the needs of the community and to be consistent with strategic planning at the provincial; 5) Informed and Innovative planning is based on relevant information and expected implications of making land use development decisions and considers innovative solutions to planning challenges; 6) Cooperative planning maximizes the use of human and material resources across regions
column14: and involves individuals
column15: municipalities
column16: First Nations and Métis people and provincial agencies as they work together toward a common vision to manage the economic
column17: physical
column18: social
column19: cultural and environmental aspects of their communities and regions. The text consists of 3 sections and 1 Appendix.

column1: LEX-FAOC163014;"Loi n°1-02 du 25 janvier 2010 portant révision de la loi n°1-016 du 20 avril 2005 portant organisation de l'administration communale.";"La loi détermine les agglomérations (commune rurale ou urbaine) qui
column2: compte tenu des critères objectifs d'expansion démographique
column3: de croissance économique et de localisation dans un périmètre urbain
column4: peuvent être érigées en une ou plusieurs communes urbaines.Par ailleurs
column5: elle définit les compétences de la commune
column6: notamment dans le domaine de la gestion des ressources naturelles
column7: de l’environnement; développement communautaire
column8: du foncier urbain et rural. Enfin
column9: elle fixe l’organisation de la commune.

column1: LEX-FAOC083760;"Chieftaincy Act
column2: 2008 (Act No. 759).";"This Act makes provision for local government in Ghana and the promotion
column3: conservation and development of customary law.There shall be a National House of Chiefs
column4: which shall be instrumental in the development and conservation of law relative to chieftaincy and customary law. There shall also be Regional Houses of Chiefs which shall have functions of dispute resolution and compilation of customary law. Each traditional area shall have a Traditional Council and may have more than one Divisional Council. A Chief may act as arbitrator in disputes regarding customary law where parties consent to arbitration. The Act also provides rules relative to the (protection of) stool property including stool lands. There shall be established by the Administrator of Stool Lands a Stool Lands Account for each region.

column1: LEX-FAOC119060;"Arunachal Pradesh Ancient Monuments
column2: Archaeological Sites and Remains Preservation Act
column3: 1987 (Act No. 4 of 1990).";"This Act provides for the preservation of ancient and historical monuments and archaeological sites and remains of national importance and for the regulation of archaeological activities in Arunachal Pradesh.The Government will have the power to declare ancient monuments or archaeological sites
column4: etc. to be protected monuments or protected areas. The Government may purchase
column5: take lease or assume the guardianship of any protected monument
column6: for its protection or preservation. An Archaeological Officer may
column7: with the sanction of the Government
column8: enter into a written agreement with the owner of any protected monument for its maintenance and preservation. In addition
column9: the Government may impose restrictions on proprietary rights in protected areas or may acquire a protected area for public purposes.The Act further provides for: archaeological excavation activities in protected areas; powers of the Government to control the moving of antiquities; compulsory acquisition of antiquities for their preservation; compensation for loss or damage to land; penalties; etc.

column1: LEX-FAOC149546;"Land and Marine Management Strategy for Grenada.";"The Land and Marine Management Strategy for Grenada is a national strategy adopted by the Government of Grenada in 2011 to guide the management of the land and marine sector. The overall goal of the Strategy is to achieve integrated national development that is environmentally sustainable. The instrument seeks to develop a coherent framework with an appropriate set of strategies that will foster productive and optimal utilization of land
column2: freshwater
column3: coastal and marine resources in an environmental sustainable manner. To achieve this
column4: the Strategy will develop a legislative policy framework for land and marine management
column5: establish network administrator organizations
column6: develop tools for management of land and marine resources
column7: and develop a framework for planning
column8: implementation
column9: monitoring and review.The overall objective is to develop and widely utilize tools for the creation of a seamless integrated system for management of land and marine resources. The aim is to implement activities and programmes related to natural resource assessment
column10: information management
column11: education and public awareness
column12: standards of codes of practices
column13: economic instruments and incentives
column14: environmental impact assessment
column15: and land use planning. In particular
column16: the Strategy will seek to ensure that individuals and economic entities are given appropriate incentives for sustainable resource use and environmental protection. It will develop economic incentives for private land owners and users to invest in soil and water conservation methods
column17: agro-forestry techniques
column18: good husbandry practices
column19: development and maintenance of tree plantations or woodlots
column20: use of appropriate livestock stocking rates; and provide tax incentives to businesses undertaking restoration and conservation.The Strategy also seeks to create efficient network administrator organizations for coordination of land and marine resource management in the country
column21: thus contributing to making agriculture and resource management more inclusive and efficient.Special consideration is given to future natural hazard and climate change impacts; and the conduction of environmental and natural hazard impact assessments for all land use plans. In addition
column22: training in environmental intelligence
column23: information management
column24: trend impact analysis and forecasting including predicting climate change future scenarios will be conducted.A main outcome of the Strategy is to create coordinating mechanisms needed to implement the Strategy and to ensure that action can be taken at all appropriate levels of decision making. The Strategy is to be implemented with support from all stakeholders
column25: including ministries
column26: agencies
column27: statutory bodies
column28: private sector

column1: LEX-FAOC009927;"Expropriation Act 1975 (No. 63 of 1975).";"This Act provides for the expropriation and taking for use of land and other property (movable or immovable)
column2: by the Minister of Public Works or by certain local authorities
column3: for public and certain other purposes. Notice of expropriation to owners as well as offers of compensation must be made. If owners do not claim specific amounts of compensation
column4: the Minister will make an offer for compensation (sects. 9-11). The criteria for determining compensation are contained in section 12. Compensation shall be determined by the Supreme Court or by arbitration in case of non-agreement between owners and expropriators (sect. 14). The Minister may withdraw an expropriation if it is in the ""public interest or otherwise expedient"" to do so (sect. 23).

column1: LEX-FAOC033874;"Designation of Nitrate Vulnerable Zones (Scotland) Regulations 2002 (S.S.I. No. 276 of 2002).";"These Regulations further implement in Scotland the requirements of Council Directive 91/676/EEC concerning the protection of waters against pollution caused by nitrates from agricultural sources. The objective of the Directive is to ensure that measures are taken to reduce and prevent nitrate pollution from agricultural sources. It provides a framework for action to reduce nitrate levels in the catchments of rivers and groundwater sources affected by such pollution
column2: and to reduce eutrophication of freshwater bodies
column3: estuaries
column4: and coastal waters. Regulation 3 designates further nitrate vulnerable zones. Regulation 4 makes provision for maps of nitrate vulnerable zones to be available for public inspection. Regulation 5 provides that the Code of Good Practice for the Prevention of Environmental Pollution from Agricultural Activity Nitrogen and Phosphorous Supplement is the code of practice established for the purposes of Article 4 of the Directive. Regulation 6 makes consequential amendments to the Protection of Water against Agricultural Nitrate Pollution (Scotland) Regulations 1996. Regulation 7 revokes the provisions of the 1996 Regulations which designate two nitrate vulnerable zones in Scotland. These nitrate vulnerable zones have been subsumed in the areas designated by these Regulations.

column1: Implements: Council Directive 91/676/EEC concerning the protection of waters against pollution caused by nitrates from agricultural sources. (1991-12-12)

column1: LEX-FAOC012656;"Rivers and Foreshores Improvement Act 1948.";"The construction
column2: operation and maintenance of works for the removal of obstructions
column3: improvement of rivers and foreshores and the prevention of erosion of lands by tidal and non-tidal waters shall be approved by the Marine Ministerial Holding Corporation and carried out by the Constructing Authority. For the purpose of constructing works for the improvement of rivers and foreshores
column4: any lands may be constituted as River and/or Foreshore Improvement Districts by the Ministerial Corporation. The latter may require owners of benefited lands within a district to contribute the whole or part of the capital cost of the work according to the provisions of Part 3
column5: Division 3 of the Act. Provisions of Part 3A (entitled "" Protection of rivers and lakes"") require the issue of a permit to: (a) make an excavation on
column6: or under protected land; (b) remove material from protected land; (c) do anything which obstructs
column7: or detrimentally affects
column8: the flow of protected waters
column9: or which is likely to do so. Stop orders may be issued by the Constructing Authority and injunctions restraining a threatened or apprehended contravention maybe granted by the Land and Environment Court. The Authority may also
column10: by notice in writing given to the person
column11: issue an impounding order. Further provisions concern the procedure for the granting of the licence
column12: the impounding of material removed from protected land and the powers of persons authorized by the Constructing Authority as regards the entry into
column13: and the inspection of
column14: lands.

column1: LEX-FAOC112999;"Decree No. 107 of the Ministry of Public Health  validating Hygienic requirements “Maximum allowable limits of concentration of total amount of quicksilver and arsenic in soil.”";"This Decree establishes maximum allowable limits of concentration of total amount of quicksilver and arsenic in soil of different categories: (a) inhabited areas; (b) industrial areas; (c) transport and engineering infrastructure land; (d) recreational land; (e) agricultural land; (f) special purpose land; and (g) other territories. Annex 1 contains the list of chemicals and authorized concentration limits’ indices.

column1: LEX-FAOC160219;"Ministerial Decree No. 79 on approval of rules regarding permit for process engineering and agricultural activities in lands affected by exogenous processes.";"By this Decree
column2: the rules were approved regarding permit for process engineering and agricultural activities in lands affected by landslide
column3: flood
column4: erosion
column5: wind erosion
column7: abrasion and volcanic mud as well as in wetlands. This Decree states that the State Committee of Geology and Mineral Resources shall be the authorized body for assessment of exposure and monitoring of exogenous geological processes and shall take measures against them. This Decree underlines that utilization of lands affected by exogenous geological processes for any purpose without the consent of the central executive bodies is prohibited.

column1: LEX-FAOC158578;"Ordonnance n° 2007-037 du 17 avril 2007 relative au Littoral.";"La présente ordonnance définit les règles relatives à l'aménagement
column2: à la protection
column3: à la gestion et à la valorisation durable du littoral. Le littoral est un patrimoine national dont la gestion doit concilier les droits des générations actuelles avec ceux des générations futures et dont les ressources naturelles doivent être exploitées de manière à garantir leur usage durable. Cette ordonnance est applicable à l’ensemble du littoral
column4: dans le respect des dispositions non contraires édictées par les législations particulières dans les secteurs de la mer
column5: de l'urbanisme
column7: de l'hydraulique
column8: du tourisme
column9: du pétrole et de la protection de l’environnement.Ce texte prévoit des outils d'aménagement du littoral (plan et directives d'aménagement du littoral
column10: et réparation des dégradations du Littoral); des organes d’aménagement du littoral. Par ailleurs
column11: il prévoit des mesures de protection et de gestion de l'état naturel du littoral
column12: des paysages
column13: des habitats et des écosystèmes; des mesures d’intervention sur le littoral. Enfin
column14: cette ordonnance prévoit des infractions et sanctions.

column1: LEX-FAOC067453;"Federal Capital Territory Act.";"This Act provides for the creation of the Federal Capital Territory for Nigeria (as described in the First Schedule to this Act) and the Federal Capital Development Authority. The Authority shall be a body corporate and shall be responsible
column2: among other things
column3: for: (a) the preparation of a master plan for the Capital city and other matters regarding land use with respect to town and country planning within the rest of the Capital Territory; (b) the provision of municipal services; and (c) establishment of infrastructural services in accordance with the master plan. The Authority may make Development Orders in respect of land and (compulsorily) acquire land for the achievement of its purposes.

column1: LEX-FAOC161940;"Ministerial Decree No. 15 on state control over use and conservation of forest fund and forest restoration.";"The Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources and the Producer Association shall carry out state control in conformity with the Forest Code. This Decree states that the supervisory authorities shall carry out state control over the following activities: (i) use of forest fund and payments of forest fees
column2: (ii) measures for soil conservation
column3: water storage and hygiene requirements
column4: (iii) use of forests in contrary to the purposes and methods of the Forest Code
column5: (iv) application of new techniques
column6: technologies and best practices for ecosystem preservation and biodiversity conservation
column7: (v) state registration
column8: state cadastre and forest monitoring
column9: (vi) documents certifying land tenure and land measures in the registered documents of land allocation
column10: (vii) growing networks of pipeline
column11: transport routes and other lines
column12: well drilling and other construction works in forest fund land
column13: (viii) research
column14: cultural
column15: tourism
column16: sport and hunting activities in forest fund land
column17: (ix) stem-only harvesting
column18: logging and timber extraction of enterprises
column19: institutions
column20: real and legal persons in the areas allocated to them
column21: (x) logging areas
column22: transport and procurement of wood and subsidiary forest reserve
column23: (xi) illegal logging
column24: (xii) afforestation and reforestation efforts in lakeside
column25: riparian area
column26: sandy place and arid land
column27: (xiii) forest planting techniques and (xiv) forestry seeds
column28: (xv) phytosanitary requirements for protecting forests from pests and diseases
column29: and (xvi) measures for forest fire fighting and equipment.

column1: LEX-FAOC084081;"Preservation of Sites and Artefacts (Amendment) Act 2008 (No. 21 of 2008).";"This Act amends the Preservation of Sites and Artefacts Act [CAP 39] in relation with the classification of objects and sites
column2: the protection of classified sites or objects
column3: appointment of Heritage Inspectors and the definition of their powers. The Minister may
column4: after consultation with the Vanuatu National Cultural Council
column5: classify as national heritage any site or object of: (a) historical significance; or (b) archaeological significance; or (c) ethnological significance; or (d) artistic significance. A register of classified sites and objects shall be kept by the Vanuatu Cultural Centre. The classification of a site by the Minister under section 2 is deemed to be an instrument creating overriding rights and interests in land as provided for by section 17 of the Land Leases Act.

column1: LEX-FAOC081822;"Law No. 979 “On mortgage”.";"This Law defines the main provisions on mortgage. Property connected with land and classified by the legislation as immovable property can be object of mortgage in accordance with mortgage agreement. When edifices
column2: buildings and structures are mortgaged
column3: the right of usage of land plot
column4: on which above‑said object are located
column5: becomes the subject of mortgage simultaneously. In such cases the right of usage of land plot is transferred simultaneously to an acquirer (buyer) of edifice
column6: building or structure when compensation from the subject of mortgage is claimed. Mortgaging rights for land plot as well as of right for other natural resources is permitted within and on conditions specified by the legislation. If the state body of mortgager and management decides to cease the right of property over mortgaged property or to cease the mortgaged rights which are not related to the direct confiscation of the mortgaged property or mortgaged rights including decision to confiscate the land plot where mortgaged house
column7: other structures
column8: edifices or plantations are located
column9: the losses caused by this decision to the mortgagee should be compensated to the mortgagee in the full volume by this state body at the expense of means which are at his disposal. Disputes about compensation of losses are settled by court or arbitrary court.

column1: LEX-FAOC009920;"Arrêté de l'Exécutif flamand portant exécution de certains articles du décret du 23 janvier 1991 relatif à la protection de l'environnement contre la pollution due aux engrais.";"Cet arrêté de l'Exécutif flamand assure l'application du décret du 23 janvier 1991 relatif à la protection de l'environnement contre la pollution due aux engrais. Il est formé par 49 articles divisés en 11 chapitres dont les plus importants sont: Déclaration (II). Tous les producteurs et utilisateurs qui
column2: au cours de l'année civile précédant l'année d'imposition
column3: exploitaient une entreprise qui avait une production d'engrais animal de 300 kg d'anhydride phosphorique ou plus
column4: ou dont la superficie des terres arables appartenant à l'entreprise s'élevait à 2 ha ou plus
column5: doivent déclarer chaque année la situation de leur entreprise à l'aide d'un formulaire de déclaration. Registre (III); De l'agrégation de transporteurs d'engrais animal (IV); Du transport d'engrais animal (V); Des restrictions quant à l'écoulement des excédents d'engrais animal (VI); De l'obligation de réception par la ""Mestbank"" (VII); De l'épandage d'engrais sur les terres arables (VIII); De la perception et du recouvrement (IX); Du contrôle (X). Douze annexes sont jointes à cet arrêté.

column1: Met en oeuvre: Décret relatif à la protection de l'environnement contre la pollution due aux engrais. (2011-02-18)

column1: LEX-FAOC151335;"Deeds Registry (Conveyancers and Notaries Public) (Fees and Charges) Regulations (Chapter 33:02).";"These Regulations stipulate that a conveyancer or a notary public shall
column2: in respect of any conveyancing work done by him or her
column3: charge the fees and disbursements set out in the Schedule hereto in relation to the matters specified therein. Fees concern
column4: among other things: the lodging of a Deed of Transfer; any conveyancing work done by him or her with respect to the lodging of mortgage bonds; notarial bonds; lodging a Deed of Hypothecation.

column1: LEX-FAOC155104;"Evidence Act (Cap. 6).";"This Act concerns evidence in judicial proceedings in all courts other than primary courts. The Act also defines relevant facts where the existence of any right or custom is in question and in general concerns evidence of existence of custom or a traditional right.

column1: LEX-FAOC155103;"Magistrates' Courts Act  (Cap. 11).";"This Act provides with respect to the jurisdiction
column2: powers and functions of magistrates' courts and for other related matters. Magistrates courts are primary courts
column3: district courts or courts of a resident magistrate. The Act defines jurisdiction proceedings relating to land and in case of customary law. A primary court
column4: in proceedings of a civil nature
column5: may order the recovery of possession of land.

column1: LEX-FAOC049496;"Arrêté du Gouvernement de la Région de Bruxelles-Capitale déterminant les normes de pollution du sol et des eaux dont le dépassement justifie la réalisation d'une étude de risque.";"Le présent arrêté du Gouvernement de la Régioin de Bruxelles-Cajpitale porte la réglementation relative à l’évaluation des risques pour la santé et l’environnement causés par une pollution du sol. La partie initiale contient la définition des termes suivants: «valeur de risque humain»
column2: «valeur de risque de dissémination»
column3: «valeur de risque pour les écosystèmes». Le texte comprend 10 articles répartis en 5 chapitres comme suit: Généralités (Ier); Risques humains (II); Risque de dissémination (III); Risque pour les écosystèmes (IV); Disposition finale (V).

column1: LEX-FAOC120891;"Recovery of Public Property (Special Provisions) Act.";"This Act provides for the recovery of private and public property from public officers that acquired such property by illegal practices making use of their office. ""Property"" for purposes of this Act includes land. For the purpose of ascertaining whether any public officer: (a) has been engaged in corrupt practices or has corruptly enriched himself or any other person; or (b) has by virtue of abuse of his office contributed to the economic adversity of the Federal Republic of Nigeria
column2: or has in any other way been in breach of the Code of Conduct
column3: the President may constitute a panel to conduct an investigation into any matter with which the officer has been concerned in the performance of his duties or to conduct an investigation into the assets of any such public officer. Offences shall be subject to trail by the Federal High Court.

column1: LEX-FAOC163160;"Medium Term Development Program of the Kyrgyz Republic.";"The Medium Term Development Program is a multi-sectoral national Program of the Kyrgyz Republic covering the period of 2012-2014. The main goal of the Program is to increase living standard of the population and poverty alleviation based on economic growth
column2: improvement of business environment and development of the efficient governance system. According to the Program
column3: agricultural policy will focus on solution of following key objectives: growth of production volume and quality of agricultural products; increasing of yield of the crop production and livestock-breeding; extension of irrigation systems
column4: water use optimization; development of the land market; cooperative development; and increasing access of the rural producers to financial resources
column5: crediting and leasing development.The Program notes that considerable attention will be paid to improving the investment climate for addressing national environmental problems. Also
column6: as part of measures to enhance biodiversity conservation and sustainable use of natural resources
column7: capacity-building activities of the network of protected areas and restoration of forest ecosystems will be carried out.Further
column8: the Government intends to ensure fair public access to sources of economic growth and to manage economic growth in the interests of the poor. The reforms underway in the system of government administration
column9: including the fight against corruption
column10: will promote transparent management in the process of forming revenues from economic activities and the effective use thereof in the interests of the poor population. The Government will continue policy of extension of the credit-financial institutions financing the agriculture in order to increase access of the rural producers to financial resources and crediting and leasing development. Access to credit funds will be ensured through both direct financial support of the state and creation of conditions to reduce interest rates of the credit institutions.Also
column11: the Government will facilitate development of the processing enterprises based on principles of the public-private partnership with further delivery of the state’s part to the private sector. The Government will provide marketing assistance to promote agricultural and processed goods on the foreign markets. Modern system of the good certification will be developed. Promotion of production of the environment friendly goods using organic technology for the export will be important area. Mechanism of monitoring of the wholesale and retail markets for agricultural goods and mechanism of price stabilization with a help of the public procurements and commodity interventions will be developed to reduce risk of speculation of the agricultural goods. The Government will prepare annual forecast of demand and supply in the agricultural sector and provide support for functioning of the informational resource. Development of the irrigation systems will be supported and measures on land market development will be performed. Finally
column12: first-priority support will be provide for the rural cooperatives and export-oriented clusters ensuring growth of production volume and creating new jobs.In the area of disasters
column13: the Government intends to create an advanced state system of Civil Protection of the Kyrgyz Republic. Addressing this will involve development of a strategic legal and regulatory framework for civil protection; improving monitoring and forecasting of natural disasters and catastrophes; timely preventive
column14: protective measures and international cooperation in the area of prevention and emergency response.Coherent actions of all stakeholders in realization of the annual plans of the Program will be ensured under general coordination of the Prime-Minister of the Kyrgyz Republic. The Program will be implemented through design and fulfillment of annual plans together with package of national projects using the budget and off-budget sources of financing. Based on monitoring data
column15: effectiveness of the program implementation will be evaluated regularly. Based on these results
column16: political decisions will be made regarding selection of alternative options on further steps in implementation of three year Program
column17: resource re-distribution and their optimal use
column18: proving coordination of efforts with the donor community
column19: better satisfaction of expectation of the society.

column1: LEX-FAOC073051;"Order No. 222 of the Ministry of Economic Development validating the Instruction on cadastre valuation of land of the newly formed plots and existing plots of land in case of change of land category
column2: type of the authorized land management or specification of land area.";"This Order establishes that the Instruction shall be applicable to: (a) formation of new plot of land; (b) change of land area or of the boundaries of the plot of land; (c) change of the type of authorized land management; and (d) transfer of a plot of land from one category to another. Land shall be classified in three categories: (1) agricultural land; (2) protected areas; and (3) land of water resources. Cadastre value of the first category shall be calculated by multiplication of average cadastre value of land at the municipal level by land area. In case of change of land area as a result of re-mapping cadastre value shall be changed in proportion to the change of land area.

column1: LEX-FAOC061310;"Coast Protection Act
column2: 1949 (Cap. 74).";"This Act provides for measures against erosion and encroachment of the coast of Great Britain by the sea. Part I of this Act provides for the protection of the coast. In sections 1 to 3 it provides for the administration relative to coast protection. It appoints the council of each maritime county
column3: borough or county district as coast protection authority for its territory. Section 2 concerns the constitution of coast protection boards for areas to be specified by the Minister. Section 3 provides for joint committees of coast protection authorities. Sections 4 to 15 concern the execution of coast protection works. Section 4 defines general powers of the coast protection authorities in this respect. The authority may prepare a scheme of works pursuant to section 6. The scheme may indicate land for which coast protection charges shall be due (sect. 7). Section 14 regulates the compulsory acquisition of land by the Minister. Section 16 requires the consent for of an coast protection authority for the carrying out of works by any other person other than the authority
column4: except that certain other authorities may carry out work on the basis of notification to the authority in accordance with section 17. Other provisions of Part I specify powers of an authority in respect of land and works for coast protection purposes.Part II contains provisions for the safety of navigation.Part III provides for management of the foreshore being Crown land. Management is transferred from the Minister of Transport to the Commissioner of Lands. Powers of the Commissioners are set out in section 38.Part IV regulates matters of miscellaneous character. It contains a list of interpretations in section 49.The First Schedule sets out the procedure for making Orders and Provisions as to validity of Orders. The Second Schedule contains provisions as to Orders restricting excavation of materials from the seashore. The Third Schedule contains repealed enactments. The Fourth Schedule specifies waters excluded for purpose of definitions of “sea” and “seashore”. (50 sections divided into 4 Parts and completed by 3 Schedules)

column1: LEX-FAOC101688;"Regulation on the detailed plan to reduce flood risk.";"This Regulation of the Government of the Republic of Slovenia
column2: which is composed of 17 articles and two Annexes
column3: sets out the content and method of preparing the detailed plan to reduce flood risk
column4: which includes the timetable for preparing the plan and its various content. The aim of preparing plan to reduce flood risks is to reduce harmful effects of floods on human health
column5: environment
column6: cultural heritage and economic activity in areas of significant impact of flooding and associated erosion. For the purposes of these provisions flood risk means the combination of probability of flood event and associated potential adverse effects on human health
column7: environment
column8: cultural heritage and economic activity. The plan to reduce flood risk is prepared for areas of significant influence of flood
column9: coordinated at the level of Danube river basin and water area of Adriatic Sea. This Regulation is composed of the following Sections: General provisions (Sec. 1); Preliminary flood risk assessment (Sec. 2); Flood risk maps (Sec. 3); Flood risk reduction plan (Sec. 4); Final provisions (Sec. 5).

column1: LEX-FAOC072901;"Land (Compulsory Sale for Redevelopment) Ordinance (Chapter 545).";"This Ordinance provides for a person who owns not less than 90 percent of undivided shares in a lot to apply to the Lands Tribunal for a compulsory sale of the whole lot for the purpose of redevelopment.Other provisions include: lot to be sold by auction and default on payment by the purchaser of the lot; registration of order for sale; and application of proceeds of sale.

column1: LEX-FAOC037518;"Land Betterment Charges Law.";"The Law provides for the application of taxes on lands on which have been carried out interventions financed wholly or partly by State funds (road building
column2: water or electricity supplies
column3: etc. etc.) that improved them. The rate tenants or owners have to pay is calculated as 50% of market value increase for that parcel of land.As far as the decisions of the board are concerned
column4: article 6 establishes that the chairman of the board shall inform the Settlement Officer of the decision taken in respect of every application. Said decision shall be communicated to the claimant and thereafter the necessary steps shall be taken by the Settlement Officer in order to give effect to the decision.

column1: LEX-FAOC138599;"Planning (Hazardous Substances) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1993 (S.I. No. 275 of 1993).";"These Regulations implement provisions of the Planning (Northern Ireland) Regulations 1991 which provide that the presence of or above the controlled quantity of a hazardous substance on
column2: over or under land
column3: requires hazardous substances consent. These Regulations
column4: among other things: (a) define the list of substances which are hazardous substances for the purposes of the 1991 Order and the controlled quantities of those substances; (b) provide exemptions from the need for hazardous substances consent; (c) establish the procedure to be followed for an application for hazardous substances consent; (d) establish the procedure to be followed on a claim for deemed hazardous substances consent and the conditions which will apply to such consents in addition to those set out in the 1991 Order; and (e) provide for the enforcement of hazardous substances control procedure.

column1: LEX-FAOC114492;"Mining Code Act (No. 1007 of 1996).";"The Act applies to stone
column2: gravel
column3: sand
column4: clay
column5: lime
column7: peat
column8: topsoil and similar elements. Exploitation of mineral deposits on land and sea must be part of a sustainable development plan which purpose is to ensure monitoring of mining areas after extraction
column9: raw material supply
column10: ensure that raw materials used are quality based and that raw materials shall be
column11: where possible
column12: replaced by waste products. The Minister of Environment sets regulations on quality and quantity of raw materials used for construction
column13: on the recycling thereof
column14: on the quantity and quality of raw materials used for the manufacturing of industrial products
column15: on the processing of certain raw material quality (abstraction) and on waste
column16: replacement products and dredging materials from the Danish marine area to be recovered and recycled as raw material. Permission for these activities is required and is granted by the municipal council authorities for the length of max. 10 years. The county council performs a mapping of mineral deposits on land to which the Minister of Environment and Energy shall set regulations. Permission for abstraction at beaches and other coastal areas where there are no contiguous land vegetation
column17: may be disclosed only with the consent of Coastal Inspector.The regional council may expropriate property not belonging to the state as well as rights over such property when the expropriation will be essential to realize a plan to promote construction. Those who conduct a mineral drilling or soil test pit
column18: in the territorial sea or the continental shelf must
column19: within 3 months after the execution
column20: report to the Geological Survey on location
column21: eventual finds in soil and water level
column22: providing samples of the perforated layer. Results of geophysical surveys and other mineral resource studies
column23: including the quality of raw materials
column24: shall be reported to the Geological Survey.The Act consists of 10 Chapters: Purpose (1); Mining and household (2); Occurrences on land (3); Occurrences in the territorial sea and continental shelf (4); Expropriation (5); Reports and studies (6); Monitoring (7); Administrative provisions (8); Actions and penalties (9); Entry into force and transitional provisions (10).

Permission for these activities is required and is granted by the municipal council authorities for the length of max. 10 years. Non-professional abstractions of more than 200 mq. per year must be reported to the municipal council. The Minister may lay down rules regarding the exploration of raw materials in special cases of research only after authorization from the municipal council.The regional council may expropriate property not belonging to the state as well as rights over such property when the expropriation will be essential to realize a plan to promote construction. column17: in the territorial sea or the continental shelf must

column1: LEX-FAOC114491;"Mining Code Act (No. 165 of 1992).";"The Act applies to stone
column2: gravel
column3: sand
column4: clay
column5: lime
column7: peat
column8: topsoil and similar elements. Exploitation of mineral deposits on land and sea must be part of a sustainable development plan which purpose is to ensure monitoring of mining areas after extraction
column9: raw material supply
column10: ensure that raw materials used are quality based and that raw materials shall be
column11: where possible
column12: replaced by waste products. The Minister of Environment sets regulations on quality and quantity of raw materials used for construction
column13: on the recycling thereof
column14: on the quantity and quality of raw materials used for the manufacturing of industrial products
column15: on the processing of certain raw material quality (abstraction) and on waste
column16: replacement products and dredging materials from the Danish marine area to be recovered and recycled as raw material. Permission for these activities is required and is granted by the municipal council authorities for the length of max. 10 years. Non-professional abstractions of more than 200 mq. per year must be reported to the municipal council. The Minister may lay down rules regarding the exploration of raw materials in special cases of research only after authorization from the municipal council.The regional council may expropriate property not belonging to the state as well as rights over such property when the expropriation will be essential to realize a plan to promote construction. Those who conduct a mineral drilling or soil test pit
column17: in the territorial sea or the continental shelf must
column18: within 3 months after the execution
column19: report to the Geological Survey on location
column20: eventual finds in soil and water level
column21: providing samples of the perforated layer. Results of geophysical surveys and other mineral resource studies
column22: including the quality of raw materials
column23: shall be reported to the Geological Survey Agency at the same time.The Act consists of 10 Chapters: Purpose (1); Mining and household (2); Occurrences on land (3); Occurrences in the territorial sea and continental shelf (4); Expropriation (5); Reports and studies (6); Monitoring (7); Administrative provisions (8); Actions and penalties (9); Entry into force and transitional provisions (10).

column1: LEX-FAOC129136;"Ministerial Decree No. 814 validating Veterinary and sanitary regulation.";"This Ministerial Decree establishes the modalities of carrying out veterinary and sanitary arrangements in accordance with veterinary norms and standards that are compulsory for all natural and legal persons. Veterinary arrangements shall be intended complex of antiepizootic measures and procedures aimed at protection of animal health
column2: prevention and liquidation of the outbreak of animal diseases. Agricultural animals must be kept clinically healthy and comply with basic physiological indices in accordance with veterinary recommendations and regulations. Manufacturing
column3: import-export and application of veterinary drugs shall be subject to compulsory registration thereof except for cases of manufacturing
column4: import and export in small quantities for registration and testing. Only healthy animals shall be authorized for slaughtering.In order to ensure cattle drive on the territory of several municipal units regional executive body shall make decision on allotment of land plots for such purposes. Persons that are the users of cattle drives and livestock passage routes for long-term use shall construct the necessary number of wells
column5: watering places and facilities for bed ground of livestock.

column1: LEX-FAOC158315;"Strategic Plan for Environment and Development.";"This document lays down the Strategic Plan for Environment and Development (SPED)
column2: which was adopted by Malta following the introduction of Directive 2014/89/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for maritime spatial planning. The SPED provides the spatial framework that supports the development of an integrated maritime policy at a national level. The plan covers the marine waters up to the 25 nautical mile limit of the Fisheries Management Conservation Zone
column3: and it does not include the administration and implementation of the provisions of the Continental Shelf Act. The SPED defines a spatial vision for the urban area
column4: the rural area
column5: the coastal zone and marine area and for Gozo. Four key thematic issues emerge from the document: (1) socio-economic development; (2) environment; (3) climate change; (4) travel patterns. The general objective for the national spatial framework is to ensure the sustainable use of land and sea resources. The Government will adopt the following sequential approach to the use of land: (a) firstly
column6: the reuse of existing developed land and buildings; (b) secondly
column7: redevelopment of existing developed land and buildings; (c) finally
column8: where no other feasible alternatives exist
column9: use of vacant land. Land take up in the rural area should be the last resort.The SPED aims at making agriculture (among other activities) more productive and sustainable. The first thematic objective relating to socio-economic development is to manage the available potential space and environmental resources on land (and sea) sustainably to ensure that socio-economic development needs are met whilst protecting the environment and limiting land take up within rural areas.Reduction of rural poverty is envisaged in relation to the vision defined for rural area. According to this vision
column10: rural area shall sustain the livelihood of farming communities through modernization of agricultural practices and diversification of compatible rural activities. Vulnerable groups are taken into consideration under the thematic objective n. 3 on socio-economic development.The SPED aims at enabling more inclusive and efficient agricultural systems. These are the main objectives concerning rural areas: (1) to facilitate sustainable rural development and the diversification of activities in order to sustain agriculture and safeguard its distinctiveness; (2) to protect and enhance the positive qualities of the landscapeand the traditional components of the rural landscape; (3) to rehabilitate
column11: upgrade and regenerate deteriorating natural environments on the basis of their type and location.As mentioned
column12: climate change is among the cross-cutting key issues of the SPED. Thematic objective n. 9 is to control greenhouse gas emissions and enhance Malta’s capacity to adapt to climate change.

column3: le 10 février 2012.";"La présente ordonnance ratifie l’Accord de Coopération portant Création du Centre Ouest-Africain de Recherches et de Services Scientifiques sur le Changement Climatique et l’Utilisation Adaptée des Terres (WASCAL)
column4: adopté à Lomé (Togo)

column7: a pour mission d’améliorer considérablement l’infrastructure
column8: la capacité de recherche et les bases de données scientifiques pour une évaluation des changements climatiques et de leur impact sur la société et les systèmes socio écologiques. WASCAL a également pour vocation de développer des solutions de nature à permettre un renforcement de la résilience des systèmes humains et environnementaux par le biais de l’adaptation de l’utilisation des terres.

column1: LEX-FAOC004824;"Land Law.";"This Act lays down basic provisions on land tenure
column2: both rural and urban. All land in Viet Nam is the property of the State
column3: but individual and corporate users
column4: both domestic and foreign
column5: can obtain from the State usufructuary rights under lease-type contractual arrangements (art. 1). Long-term leases
column7: of cropland are made for twenty years for annual crops and aquaculture
column8: and for fifty years for perennial crops
column9: both terms being renewable on expiry (art. 20). However
column10: the duration of leases granted to foreign investors shall be consistent with the terms made in regard to foreign investments by the Act on Foreign Investment (art. 83). A ceiling of three hectares nation-wide restricts the allowable size of leaseholds for the cultivation of annual crops
column11: while restrictions to the size of other leaseholds are to be determined by the Government (art. 44). A rental price is
column12: in principle
column13: payable against all leases (art. 79(4)); however
column14: the lease of agricultural land
column15: forest land
column16: land used for aquaculture and land used for salt production is exempted from payment of a rental price (art. 22). Lease rights can be traded
column17: sub-leased
column18: inherited and mortgaged
column19: subject only to the term of duration of the original lease
column20: and to conformity of the land use to the stipulations made in the original lease and to the prescriptions of land use regulations and plans in effect (arts. 3(2) and 74-78)). In particular
column21: the sub-leasing of land under cropping and aquaculture is expressly permitted
column22: for a period of up to three years
column23: renewable in ""special cases"" (art. 78).The transfer of leasehold rights is subject to payment of a tax (arts. 4 and 79(4)). To this end
column24: and
column25: in general
column26: for the purpose of calculating the rental price of land to be leased
column27: the Government is directed to evaluate land from time to time
column28: at their entire discretion (art. 12). Land under lease can be taken back by the State in specific circumstances (arts. 26 and 27)
column31: non-use of the land for twelve consecutive months without permission to do so (art. 26(3))
column32: and against payment of compensation (arts. 28 and 73(6)). Protection from unlawful encroachment by third parties and from Government is a fundamental right of all legitimate lease-holders (art. 73(6)). Such protection is available through litigation in the courts of law or before the local Government administration
column33: depending on the nature of the matter in dispute (arts. 38 and 39). Finally
column34: provision is made in the Act for the issuing of title in the form of Land Tenure Certificates (art. 36)
